He obtained his PhD in the field of “Solid State Ionics” in 2013 from Jaypee Institute of Information Technology, Noida (India). He has been awarded Dr D. S. Kothari Postdoctoral Fellowship from University Grants Commission, Government of India for research on flexible polymer electrolytes for Sodium batteries. He has completed a research project on sodium batteries sponsored by Science and Engineering Research Board, Delhi (India) under Young Scientist Scheme. His current research is mainly focused on electrolyte and electrode materials for alternative battery systems based on sodium and magnesium, and supercapacitors. Maitri Patel acknowledges the Education Department of the Government of Gujarat for providing fellowships under SHODH (ScHeme of Developing High-Quality Research; research, Ref No: 2021013725) for research. Graphical abstract A sustainable approach to improve the conventional, Lithium based and non-lithium battery systems is a pre-requisite to meet energy storage requirements of the mankind. The present and future energy requirements of mankind can be fulfilled with sustained research and development efforts by global scientists. The purpose of this review paper is to provide an overview of the fundamentals, recent advancements on Lithium and non-Lithium electrochemical rechargeable battery systems, and their future prospects. The initial part of this review paper is dedicated to the advancement and challenges faced by the conventional rechargeable batteries, such as lead-acid, Ni-Cd and Ni-MH batteries. The subsequent section of this review focuses on an in-depth analysis of two major categories of rechargeable batteries, namely lithium-based rechargeable battery systems and alternative non-Lithium rechargeable battery systems. The working principle, construction, and a few important research progress on Li-ion, Li-O2, Li-CO2 and Li-S batteries have been highlighted. The recent progress and challenges of the alternate batteries such as Na-ion, Na-S, Mg-ion, K-ion, Al-ion, Al-air, Zn-ion and Zn-air are also discussed in this review. The large gap between theoretical and practical electrochemical values for the alternate battery system must be filled by adopting a series of design architectures followed by modern instrumentation for developing next-generation batteries in a sustainable and efficient way. Keywords Conventional rechargeable batteries Li-ion batteries Li-S batteries Li-air battery Other than Lithium batteries Alternate battery systems 1 Introduction The rampant consumption of power provided by traditional and conventional means such as fossil fuels like coal, wood, and gas, has led to global environmental pollution. In order to reduce our dependence on pollution-causing fossil fuels, intensive efforts have been dedicated to the development of clean energy storage technologies. This clean energy storage technology should be sustainable, environmentally friendly, pollution-free, and easy to recycle. However, due to their dependence on specific natural environments, the combination of these technologies, backedbylarge-scale energy storage systems, is in high demand worldwide. Therefore, there is a need to develop low-cost, reliable, and sustainable battery-based energy storage systems with high power/energy densities and excellent cycle life. Rechargeable batteries are turning out to be the most successful viable energy storage technologies to meet the energy requirements using clean and green materials.A typical battery system stores energyin chemical form and its configuration consists of one or more electrochemical cells interconnected with each other to accept, store, and supply electrical energy. A rechargeable cell, on the other hand, comprises of two electrodes, the anode, and the cathode, separated by an electrolyte. Batteries are conventionally of two types:primary and secondary battery systems. Primary cells cannot be recharged and must be discarded after their lifespan expires, while secondary cells need to be recharged when their charge runs out. In a rechargeable battery system, electrons and ions flow from the anode to the cathode during discharge, while electrons and ions are forced to flow from the cathode to the anode during the charging cycle. Some of the attributes of an ideal battery are features like its long life, light weight, small size, high energy density, environmental compatibility, safety, and being cost-effective. Sadly, none of the current rechargeable batteries can fully or mostly satisfy all these challenging requirements. Most rechargeable batteries deliver capacities and energy densities far below their theoretical values. During the past decade, extensive research efforts have been devoted towards developing the advanced battery systems with large capacity, high safety standards, long cycle life, high energy and power density, fast response, and yet being low cost. Today, there is a wide spectrum of rechargeable battery systems, each of which poses specific advantages and limitations. Most rechargeable batteries suffer from gradual degradation in their specific discharge capacity with prolonged usage. The advent of electrical devices such as computers, mobile phones, and electric cars, which require long-lived energy storage capabilities, has pushed the development of battery technology to a new level. Modern rechargeable batteries are used for starting, lighting, and ignition (SLI) of vehicles and aircraft, remote monitoring stations, satellites, computers, missiles, portable communication devices, electric vehicles, spacecraft, etc. Important additional future applications of batteries may include decentralized peak power-shaving, load levelling, high-performance, and cost-effective electric automobiles. The various types of rechargeable energy storage systems such as Lead-acid, Ni-Cd, Ni-MH, Li-ion, Li-S, Li-O2, Li-CO2, Na-ion, Na-S, Mg-ion, K-ion, Al-ion, Al-air, Zinc-air and Zinc-ion battery systems as shown in Fig. 1 have been explored by the global research community to fulfil the ever-increasing energy demands. Till date, none of the present rechargeable batteries can completely meet all the demanding standards such as extended life, lightweight, compact size, high energy density, environmental compatibility, safety, and low cost. Researchers are therefore working on improving the existing battery systems and at the same time developing the alternate battery systems as well. Lead-acid batteries are the conventional secondary batteries and are the first type of battery system used for energy storage applications. Research corroborates that lead-acid batteries have the robust operation, simple control, and a lower cost than other primary batteries. However, lead-acid batteries have a few inherent limitations, such as short cycle life, low specific energy, poor low-temperature performance, and easy corrosion, which greatly limits their application. The Ni-Cd battery is another conventional secondary battery system with low-temperature operation and high-rate capabilities. For a long time, Ni-Cd was the only battery available for power tools, and it powered the early cellular phones and portable computers. However, it generally suffers from a limited energy density (∼30 W h kg−1) and possesses environmental concerns due to the usage of threatened electrode materials. Ni-MH battery is another conventional battery system for a variety of applications due to its high energy density, strong tolerance to over-discharge, and safety. However, the usage of rare-earth material-based anodes to realize these batteries contribute to their high pricing, and low-capacity values which limits their widespread usage for future applications. Among the rechargeable batteries available in the market, Li-ion batteries have revolutionized the EV industry and have become the preferred choice. The reason for its preference owes to its outstanding characteristics, high energy density, high voltage (∼3.6 V), low self-discharge rate, long cycle life, and high charging and discharging rate capability. However, Li-ion batteries possess serious safety concerns, such as the flammability of the organic electrolyte and the reactivity of the electrode materials with the organic electrolytes in the case of overcharging or short-circuiting. The natural reserves of lithium are limited to only 0.0017 wt% of the earth's crust, and its extraction process is both costly and difficult. This forces the research community to develop alternate or new rechargeable battery technologies to overcome the shortage of lithium resources and partly substitute LIBs in some energy storage applications. As LIBs approach the theoretical value of cathode/anode materials, particularly graphite anode, improved electrode materials with high energy density are in great demand for use in upcoming cutting-edge electronic devices. The research for batteries that outperform the very successful LIBs has sparked interest in Li metal negative electrodes. Li metal batteries (LMBs), which include Li-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, Li-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries, Li anode versus intercalation type cathode batteries, and so on, show a significant improvement in theoretical energy density when compared to present LIBs [1,2]. Lithium-Sulfur (Li-S) batteries are regarded as one of the most prominent competitors for existing energy storage technologies and can deliver a theoretical specific gravimetric capacity of 1675 mA h g−1 [3]. This battery technology also provides a multielectron redox couple at the sulfur cathode and, therefore, a large increase in discharge capacity [4]. However, the development of Li-S is impeded by several problems as well, which are linked to incompatibility among cathodes, electrolytes, and anodes. Polysulfide shuttle is one of the most difficult problem associated with the metal-sulfur batteries [3]. Lithium-air system is another option to provide a very high theoretical energy density of 11680 W h kg−1,which projects it as a potential competitor to other electrochemical systems. Hence, Li-S and Li-air systems are expected to be among the most potential candidates, if stability issues in these systems are solved [5]. The Li-CO2 batteries have also attracted numerous attentions since their inception on account of their highenergy storage capacity(1876 W h kg−1) and simultaneous realization of CO2 resourcing. This energy technology has the potential to play a significant role in submarines and aerospace application [6]. However, current Li-CO2 batteries still encounter a plethora of challenges such as unsatisfactory specific capacity, poor rate stability, and cycling performance [7]. The main issues linked with the Li metal rechargeable batteries are safety concerns, continuous electrolyte deterioration, and fast Li consumption. These problems are mainly related to the unwanted reactions that take place at the Li metal and liquid electrolyte interfaces [1]. Constructing a viable rechargeable Lithium battery requires extensive cycle life, rate, and safety optimization [8]. Standard electrode potentials of Na, Mg, and K are close to those of Li, and its raw materials are widely available in the earth's crust and are geographically distributed as well. This has motivated the scientific community to explore the hidden potential of energy storage systems based on Na, Mg, and K. Na-ion batteries are a highly attractive alternative technology due to the high abundance and low price of their raw materials. Much of the existing know-how can be utilized as Na-ion batteries generally function in the same manner as their Li-ion counterparts; however, their widespread commercialization is restricted due to their inferior cycling steadiness, low initial Coulomb efficiency, and low energy density [9,10]. The sodium-sulfur battery is a cost-effective large-scale stationary energy storage system at the grid level and has been commercialized in Japan [4]. Presently, several real-scale facilities based on Na-S battery technology are operating as demonstration units in countries like the United States, United Arab Emirates, and Italy [11]. The raw materials of Na-S batteries become more corrosive during their operation at high temperatures which poses serious safety concerns [4]. If a suitable compatible electrolyte is used with S as the cathode and Na as the anode, a high theoretical energy density of 760 W h kg−1 can be achieved with the Na-S battery [12]. The traditional HT Na-S battery requires a high operating temperature of over 300 °C, which limits its widespread application. So, it is inevitable to develop low-cost and safe room-temperature sodium-sulfur (RT Na-S) batteries [13]. Recently, a few Na-S batteries have been reported to show satisfactory performance at room temperature [12]. The commercialization of Na-S batteries is seriously impeded by several bottleneck problems, like poor electrical conductivity, low sulfur utilization, poor cycling stability, rate capability, the high dissolution of intermediate sodium polysulfides, and the volume change of active materials [14]. Mg has a higher melting point and volumetric capacity as compared to Li, and its ionic radius is comparable with Li [5]. Mg is well compensated by its high energy density, and its bivalency doubles its electrochemical energy storage capacity (2205 mA h g−1). Moreover, Mg metal is easy to produce, abundant in the earth’s crust and has minimal safety concerns [15]. Mg-ion batteries (MIBs) are considered to be very encouraging and leading-edge rechargeable batteries because of their lightweight, cost-effectiveness, higher energy density, and operational safety [16]. One of the most significant obstacles to overcome in the long-term use of Mg metal anodes relates to passivation, in which solid electrolyte interphases are formed, causing a large overpotential and low Coulombic efficiency. The performance of a magnesium-ion cell depends on the collective properties of the anode, cathode, and electrolyte, all of which have design efforts underway [17]. Many research efforts have been directed to overcome the drawbacks associated with the above-cited battery systems by developing novel electrolytes, anodes, and cathode materials [16]. K-ion batteries (KIBs) are low-cost, abundant natural candidates with relatively high operating potential, especially in large-scale energy storage systems. Since potassium barely reacts with aluminium, aluminium foil can be used as the current collector instead of copper foil, thereby further reducing the cost of KIBs [18]. However, due to the large ion radius of K+, most of the traditional inorganic electrode material suffers from excessive volume changes during charge-discharge, resulting in structural collapses and inflicting an irreversible specific capacity loss in K-ion batteries [19]. Al-metal has presented a novel platform for realising advanced Al-based batteries, which are assumed to be an incredibly interesting prototype in high-performance energy storage devices with more safety and higher energy density. Aluminium (Al) metal as an anode has many advantages, like large density (2.7 g cm−3), low cost, non-flammability, safety, and high theoretical capacity (2978 mA h g−1 and 8034 mA h L−1) [20]. Rechargeable Aluminium-ion (Al-ion) batteries have recently been shown as a viable option for grid-scale storage due to the abundance of required raw materials and their reliable electrochemical performance [21]. Among the various metal-air batteries, Aluminium-air batteries (AABs) are one of the most attractive choices because of their remarkable theoretical specific energy (8100 W h kg−1), light-weight, low cost,negative electrodepotential (−1.66 V vs. NHE), and abundant reserve of Al anode [22]. The application of an Al-air battery is also limited by many obstacles, like the corrosion attack on Al in an alkaline aqueous electrolyte with serious hydrogen gas evolution, which reduces the coulombic efficiency of the anode and causes serious safety hazards as well [23]. Among others, Zn-air batteries are regarded as a promising energy storage technology due to their high theoretical specific energy density (1086 W h kg−1), low cost, and safety. The Zn-air batteries have been applied in navigation, traffic signalling, and hearing devices, among other applications [24]. However, sluggish oxygen evolution reactions (OER) and oxygen reduction reactions (ORR), which are the charge and discharge reactions, respectively, in an air electrode, decrease the energy efficiency of the Zn-air battery [25]. The Zn-ion batteries possess unique advantages, such as a more earth-abundant Zn resource, a lower redox potential (−0.76 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) of Zn2+/Zn, and a higher theoretical capacity (825 mA h g−1) of the Zn anode [26]. Zn foils play a dual role as the current collector and active materials, thus minimizing production costs. ZIBs research is hindered by irreversible processes between the Zn anode and electrolytes. Unsatisfactory performance is triggered by parasitic reactions of the Zn anode, generating issues including dendrite growth, hydrogen evolution, by-product formation, and low Coulombic efficiency (CE), resulting in the capacity loss of ZIBs [27]. In this paper, the current advancements and future prospects of Lithium and non-Lithium electrochemical rechargeable battery systems are discussed. The review primarily focuses on Lead-acid, Ni-Cd, and NiMH batteries as conventional battery systems, Li-ion, Li-S, Li-air, and Li-CO2 batteries as the Lithium-based battery system and Sodium, Magnesium, Potassium, Aluminium, and Zinc based batteries as non-Li battery system. This article also provides information on the electrochemical performance, current status and trends, and the way that researchers across the globe have tailored the electrode materials and electrolytes of various batteries to improve their performance. In this review, the pros and cons that these batteries have to deal with are addressed, along with some remedies. 2 Lead-acid, Ni-Cd, and Ni-MH as conventional rechargeable battery systems 2.1 Lead-acid battery Lead-acid batteries (LABs) account for over 70% of all sales in the rechargeable market and are widely employed in people’s daily lives [28,29]. LABs are more environmentally friendly than other types of battery systems, such as Ni-Cd battery systems, and have a more robust operation, simple control, and are less expensive. LABs are not affected by the memory effect. LABs are used in the entire world’s 1.3 billion vehicles and in building backup power supplies worldwide. Furthermore, they are still present in state-of-the-art hybrid and fully electric vehicles because of their position and their established market dominance for 12-V auxiliary power supplies for electronic devices [30]. LAB has a wide spectrum of applications in uninterrupted power supplies, electric vehicles, energy storage, traction and starting, lighting, and ignition (SLI) systems [31]. The development and progress of lead-acid batteries have been quite exemplary since Plante’s discovery in 1859. The specific energy of the first lead-acid battery prototype built by Plante was 9 W h kg−1. The 1970′s world record of 70.5 W h kg−1 still exists in the name of YUASA even though it exhibited a very brief cycle life [32]. The cell consists of two active materials and electrodes as well as the electrolyte solution that acts as the conduction medium. LABs are usually made up of cells, immersed in a dilute solution of sulfuric acid (H2SO4) as an electrolyte; the positive electrode in each cell comprises of lead dioxide (PbO2), and the negative electrode is made up of a sponge lead [33]. The cell reactions and a schematic diagram for lead-acid batteries is shown in Fig. 2 [34]. In lead-acid battery system ions flow from the anode to the cathode during discharge. It is noticeable that during discharge, the HSO4 − ions go toward the negative electrode where they interact with the lead to form PbSO4 and H+ ions. Water is created at the positive electrode while the lead from the PbO2 is changed into PbSO4. The concentration of the electrolyte solution decreases as a result of the gradual development of PbSO4 in equal amounts at both electrode polarities. Therefore, sulfuric acid combines with a solid, semi-conducting conductor of electrons (lead-dioxide, PbO2, in the positive plate; metallic Lead, Pb, in the negative) at both electrodes to produce Lead sulfate (PbSO4) as a nonconductive and solid substance [34]. In LABs, the grid mainly plays the role of supporting active substances and conducting current. In terms of development history, researchers have been committed to improving the performance of the grid from the initial pure Pd to the Pb-Ca alloy to the new type of grid at present, and it has become a current trend to add additives to develop brand-new diversified alloys [35]. Chen et al. studied the critical role of aluminium sulfate as an electrolyte additive on the electrochemical performance of a lead-acid battery under high-rate charging and discharging conditions. Their research proved that aluminium sulfate in the electrolyte can affect the rapid accumulation and growth of lead sulfate formation and growth in high-rate charging and discharging processes, thereby significantly inhibiting sulfation, which ultimately reduces the internal resistance of the electrode plate and substantially improves the electrochemical performance of the LAB. It is remarkable to note that the high-rate partial charge state (1 C charging and discharging rate) cycle life (8003 times) of the battery with aluminium sulfate additive was 13 times that of the blank battery. The LAB demonstrated excellent performance via the charge acceptance test and the constant voltage/current polarization test [36]. Wang et al. investigated nitrogen-doped redox graphene as a negative electrode additive for lead-acid batteries. To suppress the sulfation of the negative electrode of lead-acid batteries, a graphene derivative (GO-EDA) was prepared by ethylenediamine (EDA) functionalized graphene oxide (GO), which was used as an effective additive for the negative electrode of lead-acid batteries. The results showed that the negative active material (NAM) contained 0.5 wt% GO-EDA additive (the N-0.5 cell), and the initial discharge capacity of the cell at a rate of 0.05 C was 171.47 mA h g−1. Meanwhile, it is encouraging to see that the high-rate partial state of charge cycle life of the N-0.5 cell under 1 C rate is 17,970 cycles, which is 280% higher than that of the blank control cell [37]. Hu et al. synthesized hierarchical porous carbon with in-situ grown carbon nanotube clusters (HPC-CNTs) by transition metal catalytic cracking and used it as an additive to inhibit the irreversible sulfation of the negative electrode of lead-acid batteries. The synthesis method not only makes a stable connection point between HPC and CNTs, but also avoids the agglomeration of CNTs. The HPC-CNTs have a rich pore structure with a specific surface area and specific capacitance as high as 1307 m2 g−1 and 164.03 F g−1 respectively. The specific capacity of the negative active material (NAM) with the addition of this material is up to 175.71 mA h g−1, which is 22.57% higher than that of the commercial NAM (143.36 mA h g−1). The cycle life of the battery under high-rate partial state-of-charge exceeds that of commercial batteries by 154%, reaching 42,946 cycles. The analysis of the action mechanism of the material in the negative electrode of a lead-acid battery provides a new material for prolonging the life of lead-acid batteries [38]. Chang et al. prepared few-layer graphene (FLG) as a conductive additive for negative electrodesinLead-acid batteries. The FLG was derived from synthetic graphite through liquid-phase delamination. The thickness of the as-synthesized FLG was determined through atomic force microscopy and it is found to be approximately 4 nm (<10 layers). In order to enhance the electrochemical performance of lead-acid batteries, pristine synthetic graphite, and FLG were introduced into the negative electrodes, which denoted NAM(G) and NAM(FLG), respectively. The initial discharge capacity of the FLG-based electrode was 4173 mA h, which was 110% higher than that of the graphite-based electrode. The cycle life of NAM(FLG) was 120 cycles, which was approximately two times higher than that of NAM(G). The impedance of NAM(FLG) was 0.226 Ω, which was significantly lower than that of NAM (16.1 Ω). Their findings indicated that incorporating FLG into the negative electrodes of batteries can result in significant performance enhancements and prolonged cycle life through the inhibition of sulfation [39]. Lead-acid batteries are among the initial battery systems utilized for energy storage applications. Although they have a low energy density, lead-acid batteries have a robust operation, simple control, low cost, and are thus widely employed in a diverse set of applications [29]. Although they have high versatility and flexible performance, the development of lead-acid batteries is considerably restricted by their low energy density and short cycle life under deep charge-discharge conditions [35,40]. To expeditiously create high-performance energy storage systems with high power densities, the development of new electrode materials is an absolute need. The use of nanostructured electrodes in lead-acid batteries has already demonstrated a reduction in the amount of time required for charging and an increase in the capacity of the batteries [41]. There has been significant progress made in the creation of carbon-based materials and their practical use in a broad variety of industries. Therefore, the introduction of carbon into the lead-based battery system will prove to be an extremely effective means of resolving challenges that have been identified in this battery system [42]. Suppressing sulfation during high-rate charging and discharging is another potential solution, which may be achieved by adding the appropriate additives to lead-acid batteries [36]. Numerous studies have shown that adding functional additives to negative active mass is an efficient way to improve battery performance. These compounds include single-wall carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), sodium polyaspartate (PASP), surfactants, carbon-based materials, and modified lignosulfonate (LS) [39]. The future generation of LABs must focus on enhancing the cycle life, energy density, and proper utilization of active materials by adopting novel approaches such as the incorporation of Pb alloys, electrodes in nanostructured form, modern carbon-based materials, and functional additives for electrodes and electrolytes. In order to address the limitations of LABs as the energy storage systems, the researchers have explored other rechargeable battery systems, such as Ni-Cd batteries. 2.2 Ni-Cd battery In 1899, a Swedish scientist named Waldemar Jungner invented the first nickel-cadmium battery, which used an alkaline electrolyte. In this rechargeable battery, nickel and cadmium electrodes are immersed in a potassium hydroxide solution [43]. These batteries are direct competitors to lead-acid batteries since they offer similar technical characteristics but with superior cycling abilities and energy density [44]. Compared with lead-acid batteries, the Ni-Cd system tolerates deep discharge and storage in the discharged state for a longer time, offers a longer cycle life, has higher specific energy and energy density, and higher specific power and power density [45]. The Ni-Cd batteries are the only batteries capable of performing well even at low temperatures in the range from −20 to −40 °C [46]. Ni-Cd batteries cool as they are recharged, as reversing the cell reaction absorbs heat energy. This allows the cell to be charged very quickly, with a full charge in 2 h or less, resulting in Ni-Cd cell efficiencies close to 70%, though some researchers have claimed an efficiency close to 85% [47]. One of the important applications of Ni-Cd batteries is military and civil aviation service [48]. To date, there have been very few commercial successes using Ni-Cd batteries for utility-scale electrical energy storage applications. For example, in 2003, Golden Valley Electric Association used 27 MW of a Ni-Cd battery bank for energy storage applications. Ni-Cd has also been used for stabilizing wind-energy systems, with a 3-MW system on the island of Bonaire commissioned in 2010 as part of a project for the island with 100% of its power derived from sustainable sources [49]. In general, Ni-Cd cells consist of positive and negative plates with separator layers interleaved between them, a potassium hydroxide (KOH) electrolyte of approximately 31% concentration by weight. A schematic representation of a Ni-Cd battery is shown in Fig. 3 [46]. The positive plate is impregnated with nickel hydroxide and the negative plate is impregnated with cadmium hydroxide [50]. The maximum cell voltage during charge is 1.3 V, and the average cell voltage is 1.2 V [51]. During the discharge cycle, Ni(OH)2 is the active material of the positive electrode, and Cd(OH)2 is the active material of thenegative electrode. During the charge cycle, NiOOH is the active material of the positive electrode, and metallic Cd is the active material of the negative electrode [46]. The overall reaction involved in energy conversion in a nickel-cadmium cell may be written as: [51]. At the cathode electrode: NiOOH + 2H2O + 2e−↔2Ni(OH)2 + 2OH− At the anode electrode: Cd + 2OH−↔Cd(OH)2 + 2e− Overall, the reaction is NiOOH + Cd + 2H2O ↔ 2Ni(OH)2 + Cd(OH)2 Ni-Cd batteries possess environmental concerns due to the disposal-related issues linked with the Cadmium content in them. Research and development work is underway to replace the cadmium electrode with a hydrogen-storing electrode to create the so-called nickel-metal hydride battery [51]. Further developments may lead to sealed, fully maintenance-free versions of this battery system [53]. Due to the high levels of Cadmium in landfills, used Ni-Cd batteries have been accumulating in massive mounds and contaminating waste streams [54]. Approximately 43% of the cathode and anode materials in scrap nickel-cadmium batteries are formed from these important materials, together with 5% plastic separators, 27% carbon steel containers, and 25% metallic plates that serve as a base for the anodic powder. Ni-Cd battery recycling has attracted a lot of attention recently in terms of academic study or commercial use due to its dangerous composition [55]. In 2018, Hung et al. studied the use of cullet and limestone as separating agents in a pyrometallurgical process for the recovery of Ni-Cd batteries. In this study, varying amounts of the separating agents were combined with used Ni-Cd batteries and heated at 1450 °C for 30 min to produce a variety of products, including slag, ingots, and flue gas [56,57]. The separation of Cd and Ni from Ni-Cd batteries was studied by Lacerda et al. using an aqueous two-phase system (ATPS) made up of water, copolymer L35, and Li2SO4. When the batteries are leached with HCl, the highest levels of Cd (99.2 3.1%) and Ni (10.6 ± 0.4)% are extracted. This new technique effectively separates the relevant metals and has the benefit of being ecologically safe [58]. In order to recover the nickel, cobalt, and cadmium that are mostly present in the form of hydroxides in Ni-Cd batteries, Hazotte et al. investigated a novel electrochemical technique. This method depends on linking electrodeposition in a single split cell to the leaching of the metal hydroxides by electrogenerated protons [59]. Ni-Cd batteries have excellent discharge characteristics. They discharge at a relatively constant voltage, even at high discharge rates and low temperatures. Additionally, they have a long cycle life (e.g., 2000 cycles), are tolerant of overcharging, and require little maintenance. Therefore, they are used to a moderate extent in both mobile as well as stationary applications [60]. Failure behaviours such as high charge voltage, loss of capacity, high self-discharge rate, internal shorts, open-circuiting, excessive oxygen pressure, generation of hydrogen, and loss of electrolytes have been characterised [61]. The Ni-Cd batteries are prohibited in several countries as the waste Ni-Cd batteries contain significant levels of Cd, heavy metal and probable carcinogen. However, discarded batteries contain important metals like Ni and Co. Due to a lack of recycling technology, spent Ni-Cd batteries are dumped in landfills as domestic trash. Therefore, low-cost, ecologically acceptable recycling technologies such as acid leaching, bio-leaching, and pyrometallurgy are required to be developed for the further widespread usage of these batteries [62,63]. 2.3 Ni-MH battery In 1990, the Japanese manufacturer Sanyo was the first to launch Ni-MH cells, which quickly established themselves as a rival to Ni-Cd batteries [64]. Nickel-metal hydride (Ni-MH) batteries have received significant attention due to their high energy density, both in terms of weight and volume, enhanced rate capabilities, and strong tolerance to over-discharge. In most ways, Ni-MH batteries are comparable to Ni-Cd batteries in terms of design and manufacturing procedures. The key difference is that the negative Cadmium-based electrode has been replaced with an electrode made of a hydrogen-storing metal alloy. Furthermore, sealed Ni-MH cells are simple to build because the oxygen and hydrogen gases that are formed during overcharge and over-discharge are efficiently consumed, enabling a prismatic design with improved packing and heat management capabilities. These batteries are also free from dendrite growth and the memory effect caused by recrystallization, and they are free of hazardous elements such as Lead, Cd, Hg, and asbestos. Ni-MH is an environmentally friendly technology as it does not contain Cadmium and allows the easy recycling of its constituent items. Almost all presently used Ni-MH batteries employ a rare earth Mischmetal-nickel based alloy (MmNi5-type) with cobalt, manganese, and aluminium fractions [65,66]. The Ni-MH battery has a wide range of energy storage applications in electric cars, portable devices, and prospective industrial standby uses like uninterruptible power supplies (UPS). This battery system is a good choice for usage in hybrid electric cars (HEVs) as well, due to its flat discharge behaviour, excellent high rate, and long cycle life. The main hurdle for HEV applications, however, is the rapid rate of self-discharge, with the battery losing 5%–20% of its capacity within the first 24 h after its complete charging [67]. Ni-MH batteries have an anode made of hydrogen-absorbing alloys (MH), a cathode made of nickel hydroxide (Ni(OH)2), and a potassium hydroxide (KOH) electrolyte. During the charging process, the hydrogen atom separates from Ni(OH)2 and is absorbed by the MH alloy. During the discharge, process the hydrogen atom separates from the MH alloy and combines with NiOH to generate Ni(OH)2. The general electrochemical reactions of Ni-MH cells are as follows [68]. M + e− + H2O → MH + OH− [Anode] Ni(OH)2 + OH− →NiO(OH) + H2O + e− [Cathode] M + Ni(OH)2 → MH + NiO(OH) [Net cell reaction] where ‘M’ is an intermetallic alloy capable of forming a metal hydride phase. Schematic diagram of the electrochemical reaction processes in a Ni-MH battery is shown in Fig. 4 . [68]. The intrinsic properties of the electrode materials have a significant impact on the electrochemical performances of Ni-MH batteries. Only a few hydrogen storage alloys, such as AB5-type alloys, AB2-type alloys, Mg-based alloys, Ti-V-based alloys, and A2B7-type or AB3-type rare earth (RE)-Mg-Ni-based superlattice alloys, have been developed as anode materials for Ni-MH batteries [69]. However, numerous significant issues with these anode materials, including the limited capacity of AB5 alloys, the sluggish activation of AB2 alloys, the poor kinetic characteristics of Mg-based alloys, and the high cost of production make them unsuitable for use in practical applications. Finding novel anode materials for Ni-MH batteries with great performance and cheaper cost than traditional electrode materials has recently been the subject of research. Significant research efforts are directed to enhance the energy density, high-rate discharge ability, and cycle life offered by these alloys. Perovskite-type oxides e.g. ABO3 are now extensively employed in industrial applications such as fuel cells, catalysts, corrosion prevention, and electrochemical capacitors [70]. Xu et al. used non-alloyed but catalysed Mg as an anode for Ni-MH batteries. Nanosized Mg was treated with 5 mol% TiF3 to accelerate hydrogen sorption. Using room-temperature/high-temperature ionic liquids and an alkaline polymer membrane as a working electrolyte and encapsulating the electrode have been researched to avoid Mg passivation. The room-temperature ionic liquid-based batteries have limited capacity and coulombic efficiency while the high-temperature ionic liquid-based batteries offer high coulombic efficiency (99.7%) and reversible capacity (398.8 mA h g−1). The alkaline aqueous electrolyte has the maximum output voltage (1.14 V) [71]. Deng et al. fabricated La(1−x)SrxFeO3 perovskite-type oxides having single-phase orthorhombic (x = 0.2) and rhombohedral (x = 0.4) structures as negative electrode for Ni-MH battery. La(1−x)Sr x FeO3 oxide electrode discharge capabilities increase with temperature and decrease with discharge current density. When the temperature rises from 298 to 333 K, their initial discharge capacity increases from 324.4 to 543.0 mA h g−1 (when x = 0.2) and from 147.0 to 501.5 mA h g−1 (when x = 0.4) at 31.25 mA h g−1 [72]. In the Ni-MH battery, nickel hydroxide and its derivatives with typical layer structure are used as cathode materials which possess α and β crystal forms. It has also been discovered that certain high-valence metal ions (e.g., Al3+, Co3+, and Fe3+) substitute some of the Nickel ions in the formation of new stable layered double hydroxides (LDHs), hence retaining specific capacity and considerably enhancing the cycle life [73]. Zha et al. claimed that the specific capacity of Co/Ni LDHs is up to 250.69–339.58 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 [74]. Nie et al. used a simple stable dual complexation-precipitation process to create Ni/Al layered double hydroxides (Ni/Al LDHs) with 3D spherical structure. XRD and CV studies by the authors reveal that doping Al increases the distance between Ni-Al layers, thereby considerably enhancing the specific capacity of the resulting materials. At a current density of 1 A g−1, the specific capacity of the produced material with 18% Al may reach 383.4 mA h g−1. Furthermore, the material made of Ni/Al LDHs retains 97.6% of its original capacity after 5000 cycles at a current density of 10 A g−1, demonstrating remarkable cycling stability and durability [73]. For commercial Ni-MH batteries, the current cathode material is spherical β-Ni(OH)2. However, because of their relatively low theoretical capacity, low conductivity, and other factors, Ni-MH battery development is severely constrained. For decades, tremendous efforts have been made to address the above cited difficulties by nano crystallization, surface treatment, the addition of carbon-based hybrid materials, and the substitution with α-Ni(OH)2. Carbon-based hybrid materials have been employed in a range of energy storage applications because of their low weight and flexibility, which may considerably increase the rate performance and stability of the battery. The addition of carbon materials such as graphene and porous carbon to β-Ni(OH)2 may boost the discharge capacity and cycling stability. Owing to its large theoretical capacity, α-Ni(OH)2 has been recognised as a direct substitute for β-Ni(OH)2. However, α-Ni(OH)2 is difficult to be maintained in a stable state in strong alkaline solution. Inserting trivalent metal ions (such as Al3+, Mn3+) and integrating some anions (such as NO3−, CO3−) can be an important approach to increase the stability of α-Ni(OH)2 in KOH solution [75]. The electrolyte is the medium that offers the ion transport system between a cell's cathode and anode. Potassium hydroxide (KOH) based electrolyte is mostly used in Ni-MH batteries. Comparison research with two concentrations of KOH electrolytes: 1 and 8 M was reported by Khaldi et al. For the 1 and 8 M KOH electrolytes, respectively, the maximum capacity values are 295 and 237 mA h g−1, the capacity losses after 23 cycles are 10% and 58%, the polarization after activation is 110 and 360 mV, and the thickness of the corrosion layer on the electrode surface is 7 and 42 nm, respectively. These results demonstrated that using 1 M solution instead of 8 M solution improves the performance of Ni-MH battery and yields superior outcomes [76]. The most promising negative electrode material for Ni-MH batteries has been identified as magnesium-based alloys, which have undergone significant research. Unfortunately, the rapid electrochemical capacity degradation and low-rate capability of Mg-Ni-based alloys severely restrict their practical applications. Due to the extremely low oxidation potential of magnesium, amorphous Mg-Ni-based electrodes quickly corrode in strong alkaline electrolytes, causing capacity degradation. Numerous attempts including the surface modification, composite formation, element substitution, electrolyte modification, have been adopted to avoid the corrosion of the Mg-Ni-based alloy anodes. Huang et al. investigated a high-concentration tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAH) aqueous electrolyte with a unique hydrate structure that offered outstanding cycle stability and high capacity for Mg-based alloy anodes. In this electrolyte, the Mg0.4Ti0.1Ni0.5 alloy anode has a maximum discharge capacity of 466 mA h g−1. Furthermore, the corrosion of the electrode can be reduced by in-situ development of a Cu coating on the Mg0.4Ti0.1Ni0.5 electrode surface and adding 0.01 M of Cu(OH)2 in TMAH electrolyte. In this manner, the reversible capacity may reach up to 313 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. A high conducting Cu coating is an another approach to improve the rate capability of the electrode by encouraging the charge transfer at the interfaces [77]. Ni-MH batteries have powered household electronics and hybrid electric cars since the 1990s. Its high-power density, no contamination, no memory effect, broad operating temperature, and safety make it an essential battery family member. Its energy density is lower than Li-ion batteries (LIB), which is Ni-MH's biggest hurdle. Thus, Ni-MH batteries have long sought higher-capacity anode materials. To increase capacity, rare earth–Mg–Ni-based AB3 type alloys, ZrMn2-based AB2 type alloys, novel Ti-V-based alloys, and Mg-based alloys have been studied. Mg and Mg-based alloys are popular hydrogen storage materials due to their high theoretical capacity (2200 mA h g−1 for MgH2) and abundance. Unfortunately, rapid electrochemical capacity decay, corrosion, passivation, and poor rate capability limit practical applications of amorphous Mg-Ni-based alloys. By doing the surface modification, composite formation, element substitution, and electrolyte modification one can prevent the corrosion of Mg-Ni-based alloy anodes. The next-generation cathode material for Ni-MH batteries, α-Ni(OH)2 has been considered to be quite promising. The specific capacity of α-Ni(OH)2 is larger theoretically (482 mA h g−1) and practically (270–477 mA h g−1) compared to commercial β-Ni(OH)2, which has comparatively low specific capacities in both theory (289 mA h g−1) and reality (220–282 mA h g−1). By doping additional cations like Al3+, Co2+, Zn2+, Mn3+, or Yb3+ can improve the poor stability of α-Ni(OH)2 in the alkaline electrolyte [77,78]. 3 Developments on lithium-based battery systems Lithium metal is an ideal electrode material for Li batteries due to its low density (0.534 g cm−3), low reduction potential (−3.04 V vs. SHE), high theoretical specific capacity (3861 mA h g−1 and 2061 mA h cm−3). The low density of Lithium metal contributes to weight reduction and supports superior gravimetric energy and power density values in Lithium based batteries. Lithium metals readily give up electrons and have the lowest reduction potential in the alkali group. This means that lithium-based batteries have a relatively high voltage compared to other types of batteries, and a higher voltage translates to storing more energy. The lithium metal anode has been identified as one of the most promising anode materials for future high-energy battery technologies, whether it is used in an all-solid-state, a semi-solid state, or a liquid cell configuration in conjunction with a high-capacity cathode material, such as intercalation metal oxides, sulfur, or oxygen [79]. Li-Based batteries mainly include Li-ion batteries, Li-S batteries, Li-O2 batteries and Li-CO2 batteries. The working principle, construction, and a few important research progress on the battery technology, along with key advantages and limitations, are highlighted in the subsequent sections. Several categorization systems for Li-based batteries were put forward based on the types of electrodes and electrolytes and their physical states. A cell using lithium metal or a lithium compound as the anode is referred to as a lithium battery (LB). Li-Based batteries mainly include Li-ion batteries, Li-S batteries, Li-O2 batteries, and Li-CO2 batteries. LIBs refer to a class of secondary (rechargeable) devices where the electrolyte is typically a lithium salt mixed in a combination of organic solvents and both electrodes are intercalation materials. In a Lithium-air/O2 battery (LAB), a liquid or polymer-based electrolyte is used to electrochemically connect a lithium anode with the atmosphere via a ceramic composite cathode. A lithium metal anode, an organic liquid electrolyte, and a sulfur composite cathode make up lithium-sulfur batteries (LSB), another form of Li-based battery that is of significant interest. An organic electrolyte-filled separator and a metal Li anode are both employed in Li-CO2 batteries. So, in Li-metal based batteries like Li-S, Li-O2, and Li-CO2 battery systems, Li-metal is used as an anode. In Li-ion based batteries negative electrodes, i.e., anode materials, are traditionally constructed from graphite and other carbon materials. 3.1 Li-ion battery Lithium-ion (Li-ion) batteries have become an integral part of our daily lives [80]. Society's increasing use of portable electronics, the need to balance the fluctuating output of renewable energy sources, and the rise of electric vehicles have put tremendous pressure on the further improvement of Li-ion batteries. As a result, Li-ion batteries are studied extensively to optimize the existing technology and to discover new and more advanced battery materials [81]. LIBs are currently the most widely applied technology for mobile energy storage and are commonly used in cell phones, computers, power tools, and electric vehicles (EVs) [82]. These batteries are widely studied due to their high energy and power density, high discharge capacity, high columbic performance (nearly 100%), lack of memory effect, prolonged life cycle, higher gravimetric, excellent stability, volumetric energy density with a lower self-discharge rate, and calendar-life [83]. M.S. Whittingham from Binghamton University first proposed LIBs in the 1970s [84]. Two more decades passed before Sony commercialized the first rechargeable Li-ion batteries in 1990 [85]. LIBs consist of a positive and a negative electrode separated by an electrolyte solution containing dissociated salts, which enable ion transfer between the two electrodes [85]. While charging, Li+ de-intercalates from the cathode materials (LiCoO2, in this case), diffuses into the electrolyte and moves through the separator nanopores to intercalate into the anode material. Meanwhile, electrons move in the opposite direction through the external circuit to maintain electroneutrality. During discharging, Li+ ions transport from the anode side back to the cathode. The charge and discharge reactions are as follows [86,87]. Cathode: LiCoO2 ↔ Li(1- x ) CoO2 + xLi+ + xe− Anode: 6C + xLi+ + xe− ↔ Li x C6 Overall: LiCoO2 + 6C ↔ Li(1- x )CoO2 + Li x C6 The four most commonly used cell configurations in LIBs include cylindrical, prismatic, coin, and pouch cells. A typical Li-ion cell configuration is shown in Fig. 5 . From the early stages of R&D on Li-ion batteries, it is clear that transition metal oxides and sulfides like lithium cobalt oxide, lithium nickel oxide, lithium iron phosphate, lithium manganese oxide, lithium nickel manganese cobalt oxide, etc. can serve as excellent reversible cathode materials [88]. Lithium-cobalt oxide-based battery materials dominate in computer, communication, and consumer electronics-based LIBs due to their easy processing, and high-voltage operation [89]. LiCoO2 is a popular cathode material for LIBs owing to its high volumetric energy density, which might be increased further by charging to high voltages. However, the practical application of high-voltage charging is hampered by LiCoO2′s structural instability in the profoundly delithiated state, as well as the associated safety issues. Through trace Ti-Mg-Al co-doping, Zhang et al. achieved stable cycling of LiCoO2 at 4.6 V (against Li/L+). They reported the integration of Mg and Al into the LiCoO2 lattice, which suppresses the undesirable phase transition at voltages over 4.5 V, using cutting-edge synchrotron X-ray imaging and spectroscopic methods. They also showed that Ti segregatedstrongly at grain boundaries and on the surface, changing particle microstructure while stabilizing surface oxygen at high voltages. Full pouch cells (∼2.8 A h) with bare LCO or TMA-LCO cathodes and commercial graphite anodes were built for possible practical applications and cycled at room temperature in the voltage range 3.0–4.55 V (corresponding to 4.6 V vs. Li/Li+) [90]. A passive layer formed on the surface of lithium cobalt oxide (LCO) is thought to be a useful method for improving electrochemical performance. Shen et al. used a sol–gel approach to modify (LCO) with electrically conductive Al-doped ZnO (AZO) coating. The electronic conductivity of the AZO-coated LCO material was greater than that of the pure sample. The LCO sample coated with 2% AZO demonstrated good cyclability, with a capacity retention of 98.2% after 50 cycles at ambient temperature in the voltage range of 2.75–4.5 V. More notably, this material demonstrated exceptional rate capability, delivering a relatively high capacity of 156 mA h g−1 at the rate of 8 C (1600 mA g−1), equating to 86.6% of the capacity at the rate of 0.1 C [91]. Qin et al. reported a solid-state sintering strategy by employing and introducing La2O3 nanoparticles to promote the homogenous distribution of the grains and construct 3D continuous Li-ion transport networks along the grain boundaries. The LaLiO2 Li-ion conductor is synthesized by combining the excess La2O3 nanoparticles with the gas Li2O. The Li-ion conductivity reaches 1.12 × 10−3 S cm−1 (64% higher than the pure LLZTO electrolyte) with a relative density of 98.1%. The Solid-state lithium batteries with LiFePO4 cathode achieved a discharge capacity of 128.8 mA h g−1 and a coulombic efficiency over 99% after 600 long-term cycles (0.5 C) at room temperature [92]. Yu et al. designed and reported two novel air-sensitive Li-rich organic cathodes (m-TP4OLi andp-TP4OLi) for the first time. The structure-performance relationship for the two organic cathodes was compared. Using an organic anode of lithium terephthalate (Li2TP), the resulting Li2TP IIp-TP4OLi all-organic Li-ion batteries can deliver the peak discharge capacity of 330 mA h g−1 cathodein 1–3.4 V, corresponding to the high energy density of ∼574 W h kg−1 cathodeusing the median voltage of 1.74 V. Furthermore, the fabricated graphite IIp-TP4OLi Li-ion batteries can show the peak discharge capacity of 305 mA h g−1 cathodein 1.5–3.4 V with a high median voltage of 2.4 V, resulting in the peak energy density of ∼732 W h kg−1 cathode(2.4 V × 305 mA h g−1). Meanwhile, the graphite IIp-TP4OLi Li-ion batteries exhibit impressive device stability over 20,000 cycles [93]. For improving LCO following strategies can be used: Doping LCO at high voltages improves delithiation potential, electronic/ionic conductivity, redox reaction, and structural reversibility. Protective coatings on LCO particles, films, or electrodes increase high-voltage cyclability and thermal stability like Electrochemically inactive coatings: oxides, fluorides, phosphates, or silicates; Li-ion conductive coatings: Li-containing cathode materials, inorganic fast Li-ion conductors, Li-ion conductive polymers, and others (highly polarized dielectric materials (TaTiO3), surface P doping (Li–O–P glass phase); electron conductive coatings: carbon-based materials, electron conductive polymers, and modified inactive coatings. Doping and coating together may improve LCO high-voltage performance. To increase LCO high-voltage performance, nanostructured LCO structures with diverse morphologies may be created. High-voltage LIBs employ LCO cathodes with nanotubes, desert-rose structures, nanoplates, nanowires, flake-like structures, cubes, spheres, and chain-like structures [94]. Negative electrodes, i.e., anode materials, are traditionally constructed from graphite and other carbon materials, although newer silicon-based materials are being increasingly used. These materials are used because they are abundant, are electrically conducting, and can intercalate lithium ions to store electrical charge with modest volume expansion [95]. Wang et al. designed a binder-free, high-silicon content flexible anode for Li-ion batteries. They designed a cellulose-based topological micro scroll by the self-rolling of cellulose nanosheets to form a binder-free, flexible, and free-standing electrode comprising an unprecedented 92% silicon content. In the micro scroll, carbon-coated silicon nanoparticles are anchored on conductive carbon nanotubes and subsequently confined in cellulose carbon rolls with enough internal voids to accommodate the volume expansion of silicon; thus, a uniform dispersion of silicon with high reactivity was achieved. This structure shows an ultrahigh electrode-specific capacity of 2700 mA h g−1, excellent cycling stability, and a commercial-level areal capacity (5.58 mA h cm−2) [96]. Paravannoor et al. demonstrated a novel electrode design based on porous Si nanostructures for Li-ion batteries to enhance their performance. Silver nanoparticles are embedded within the silicon aerogel-based structures in a viable approach and used in combination with room-temperature ionic liquid (RTIL) electrolytes. A first discharge capacity as high as 2712 mA h g−1 was obtained, which remained at 1899 mA h g−1 at the end of 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1 [97]. Yang et al. [98] prepared a microporous polymer through the Sonogashira-Hagihara cross-coupling reaction of Br-functionalized porphyrinic monomer and alkynyl-based monomer. Due to the existence of abundant active sites, rich porosity, a narrow bandgap, and inhibition of dissolution in the electrolyte, this porphyrinic porous polymer can be used as anode material for Li-ion batteries. To investigate the electrochemical Li storage properties of the as-prepared polymers, 2032 coin-type half cells with polymer work electrodes, Li counter/reference electrodes, and 1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC electrolyte were employed. The electrochemical performance of the CMP-Por electrode is shown in Fig. 6 . [98]. The polymer electrodes were initially measured by cyclic voltammetry (CV) at 0.5 mV s−1 from 0.01 to 3.0 V vs. Li/Li+ for the first five cycles as shown in Fig. 6(a). Double irreversible peaks at 1.2 and 0.5 V vs. Li/Li+ may be seen in the first cathodic process, but they vanish in subsequent processes due to the creation of a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer. Fig. 6(b) shows CMP-Por electrode galvanostatic discharge-charge curves at 0.5 A g−1 at 1st cycle and 1 A g−1 at 6th, 100th, 500th, and 1000th cycles. The cell has 626/328 mA h g−1 discharge/charge capacities and 52.4% Coulombic efficiency (CE) in the first cycle which subsequently becomes 1198/1204 and 99.5% after 1000th cycle. At 1000th cycle, the CMP-Por electrode's specific capacity is 1200 mA h g−1 with an average CE above 99.5%. The LP-2 electrode's specific capacity is 420 mA h g−1 at 1000th cycle, compared to 294 mA h g−1 at 6th cycle. CMP-Por electrode has excellent rate capability, with average discharge/charge capacities of 302/281, 281/275, 264/261, 255/253, 237/236, and 297/292 mA h g−1 at 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 5, and 1 A g−1 (Fig. 6d). As shown in Fig. 6(e), the CMP-Por electrode achieves a specific capacity of 226 mA h g−1 at 3 A g−1 after activation (6th cycle) and 546 mA h g−1 after 5000th cycle with an average CE over 99.9%, indicating its strong durability through repeated lithiation and delithiation procedures [98]. The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is a fatal decisive component for battery performance and is formed when the metal comes into contact with the electrolyte. This layer functions as a new interphase between the two original phases, allowing ions to flow through but preventing electron transport. In most cases, SEI is made up of a variety of organic oligomers and inorganic species, which are woven together to form a heterogeneous mosaic structure [99]. Due to the significant contribution of anion to the solvation sheath, the desolvation manner of lithium-ion in the high-concentration electrolyte is significantly changed. Higher desolvation activation barriers are a concern due to the strong anion-ion Coulombic contact between anion and cation. Yamada et al. indicatedthat the desolvation energy barrier is jointly determined by a number of factors, such as the types of Li salt and solvent, electrode materials, the presence or absence of SEI films, and the composition and structure of SEI films [100]. Low-cost, high-conducting, electrochemically stable, naturally abundant, and environment-friendly electrolytes are required for rechargeable batteries [101]. Most of the electrolytes used in commercial LIBs are non-aqueous solutions that contain lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) salt dissolved in organic carbonates. However, new organic solvents and lithium salts are needed to improve LIBs energy, power density, and safety. Due to typical carbonate solvents' limited voltage stability, developing LIBs has required finding a high-voltage electrolyte. To address the issues of non-aqueous electrolytes, researchers are working on different electrolytes like aqueous electrolytes, ionic liquid electrolytes, solid polymer electrolytes, gel polymer electrolytes, and hybrid electrolytes [102]. According to Zhang et al., PVdF-HFP membranes with honeycomb-like porous topologies lead to 86.2% electrolyte uptake, exhibit ionic conductivity of 1.03 × 10 −3 S cm−1 at ambient temperature, have strong thermal stability up to 350 °C and fire-proof capabilities, and have electrochemical stability up to 5 V. They were of the opinion that the porous structure's various sizes were responsible for the performance. Due to the presence of the oligomeric ionic liquid (OIL), it was employed to create PVdF-HFP based GPEs [103]. Currently, the battery industry is dominated by Li-ion batteries due to their high energy density, high power density, high discharge capacity, and long cycle life. Safety, durability, uneven lithium resources, and high cost impose limitations on the wide applications of LIBs in electric vehicles. LIBs must operate within their safe and reliable operating temperature and voltage windows. Exceeding the restrictions of these windows will lead to rapid attenuation of battery performance and even result in battery failures or explosion [104]. The practical value of the energy density of Li-ion battery is ∼265 W h kg−1. Extensive efforts should be done to increase this value for future energy demands. The future research on Li-ion batteries must focus on addressing the issues related to low electrical conductivity, sluggish Li+ diffusion, unfavourable electrolyte interactions, poor thermal stability, rapid volume expansion, mechanical brittleness, an unstable solid-electrolyte interface (SEI), drastic volume fluctuations during charge and discharge cycles. Building artificial solid-electrolyte interfaces, constructing host structures for Li deposition, adjusting electrode surface features, and using the surface coating to decrease the side reaction will be the research directions needed to take the Li-ion batteries to the next level [105,106]. 3.2 Li-S battery Recently, it has been argued that Li-ion technology might have reached its limit, especially when it comes to the energy requirements for the next generation of electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs). LSBs could represent a good alternative due to their improved performance with respect to existing Li-ion technology [107]. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, proposed in the 1960s, are now regarded as one of the best candidates for energy storage beyond LIBs [3]. In 1960, the first Li-S primary battery was developed by Herbert and Ulam in 1962.It was reported in 1979 (Rauh et al., 1979) that a rechargeable Li-S battery was constructed using Li foil as the anode, 5 M S (in Li2S n form), and 1 M LiAsF6 dissolved in THF [108]. The high-energy and low-cost features make the Li-S battery a promising energy storage technology in practical applications such as portable devices, electric vehicles, and grid storage when coupled with the harvesting of solar or wind renewable energies [109]. Among the various types of rechargeable batteries, this system is a very attractive candidate, because of its high theoretical capacity (1675 mA h g−1) which is 2–3 times higher than the best performing Li-ion equivalents, high theoretical power density, and wide temperature range of operation. Moreover, elemental sulfur benefits from advantages such as natural abundance, by-products in the petroleum industry, low cost, excellent safety due to its intrinsic protection mechanism from overcharge, suitability for multi-electron reactions and conversion, and its non-toxicity [110] and metallic lithium has a very high electronegativity while possessing the lowest density among all metals, leading to its highest specific capacity (3861 mA h g−1) and thus has been considered to be the best candidate for rechargeable battery anodes [111]. Li-S batteries are relatively light because of the low atomic weight of lithium and moderate atomic weight of sulfur. A Li-S battery encompasses three major components: sulfur-carbon composite cathode, Li-metal anode, and polymer or liquid electrolyte. The anode and cathode are typically separated by a porous separator [112]. A schematic showing the operation of a Li-S cell and typical charge/discharge profiles for a Li-S battery is shown in Fig. 7 . Lithium metal undergoes oxidation during the discharge process, thereby releasing the lithium ions and electrons. In order to complete the circuit and conduct the electrical current, lithium ions migrate from the negative electrode to the positive electrode via the electrolyte, while electrons move over the exterior electrical circuit. When lithium ions and electrons are accepted, elemental Sulfur at the positive electrode gets converted into the lithium sulfide (Li2S). During the charging process, the vice versa takes place [114]. As an example, consider the reactions [3,107]. Cathode (+): S8 + 16Li+ + 16 e− →8 Li2S Anode (-): 16Li → 16Li+ + 16 e− Overall: 16Li + S8 → 8 Li2S In reality, this reaction takes place across a number of steps as following. Charge and discharge reactions: S8 + 2e−+2Li+↔Li2S8 Li2S8 + 2e−+2Li+↔4Li2S6 2Li2S6 + 2e−+2Li+↔3Li2S4 Li2S4 + 2e−+2Li+↔2Li2S2 Li2S2 + 2e−+2Li+↔2Li2S In general, two discharge plateaus appear at 2.3 and 2.1 V, as shown in Fig. 7(b). The solid–liquid two-phase reduction of sulphur to Li2S8, which can be expressed by the equation S8 + 2 e− + 2Li+ ↔ Li2S8, is the first plateau. The second plateau is the reduction of low-order polysulfides to solid Li2S2 and Li2S in a liquid–solid two-phase reaction [3]. Higher-order polysulfides constantly diffuse to the anode, where they are gradually reduced by the elemental lithium to lower polysulfides. The soluble lower polysulfides then diffuse back to the cathode to be deoxidized into a longer chain. This causes the so-called internal “shuttle” effect [115]. However, there are several obstacles that need to be addressed before the practical application of Li-S batteries. These obstacles are: (1) the insulation of sulfur and lithium sulfide, which results in low utilization of active materials. (2) The polysulfide shuttle corrodes the lithium anode and contributes to self-discharge and low coulombic efficiency. (3) Capacity fade due to degradation of cell components (4) Lithium dendrite is formed by the non-uniform deposition of lithium ions. In recent years, many efforts have been made to deal with the above obstacles for Li-S batteries [112,116]. In order to advance Li-S batteries, a variety of strategies have been carried out to address these problems, including the optimization of electrolytes or additives, the preparation of sulfur-conductive polymer composites and sulfur-carbon composites, and the protection of the lithium anode [114]. Various innovative cathodes are designed with different dimensions (0-D, 1-D, 2-D, 3-D), electrical conductivity (nitrogen-doped carbon, functional CNTs, etc.), pore size (micro-, meso-, macro-), and various polar species (metal-oxides and sulfides) for efficient polysulfide anchoring [117]. In order to fabricate Li-S batteries, the cathode materials occupy a paramount position. There are several reports on cathode materials for Li-S batteries, such as carbon-based materials, metallic oxides, and conductive polymer matrix materials that are being compounded with elemental sulfur to prepare sulfur-based cathodes, etc [118]. Guo et al. reported sulfur-impregnated disordered carbon nanotubes as cathode material for the lithium-sulfur battery. The obtained sulfur-carbon tube cathodes demonstrate superior cyclability and Coulombic efficiency. More importantly, the electrochemical characterization indicates a new stabilization mechanism of sulfur in carbon induced by heat treatment [119]. Zhang et al. fabricated a 3D Graphene Nanosheet@Carbon Nanotube (GN-CNT) matrix as the cathode for a Li-S battery through a simple one-pot pyrolysis process. Prepared GN-CNT composite exhibits high initial discharge capacity and slow capacity decay of 0.08% and 0.09% per cycle, respectively, at 0.5 and 1.0 C within 500 cycles [120]. Zhang, Duan, et al. used graphene micro sheets (GMs) as a special conductive carbon support to load sulfur in the Li-S cathode Because the GMs were coated with natural silicate residues, the composite could suppress polysulfide migration and inhibit the shuttle effect. In addition, the GMs showed good conductivity, low defect density, and small sheet sizes [118,121]. Electrochemical performances of Li-S batteries of GMs/S cathode and lithium anode is shown in Fig. 8 . Fig. 8(a) shows cyclic voltammogram (CV) curves at 0.1 mV s−1 within a potential range of 1.7 to 2.8 V (against Li/Li+). Two anodic oxidation peaks and two cathodic reduction peaks were found due to sulfur-lithium multi-step reactions. Fig. 8(b) shows GMs/S cathode electrochemical impedance spectrometry (EIS). At 2.35 V, the batteries were pristine (before charge/discharge cycling) and cycled (10 cycles). Both cells have electrolyte resistances of about 3 Ω. After 10 cycles, this resistance increased, raising electrolyte viscosity and lowering LIBs. By cycling charges/discharges at different current densities, the composites' rate capacities are shown in Fig. 8(c). In Fig. 8(d), GMs/S (38%) and GMs/S (62%) samples perform at 0.1 C to 2 C. GMs/S cathode performs better with decreased sulfur concentration, demonstrating graphene's usefulness. Discharge capacities were 863, 776, 671, 603, and 253 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, and 2 C (50% of S) (Fig. 8e). When the current density was immediately turned back to 0.2 C, 50 wt% sulfur maintained a discharge capacity of 776 mA h g−1. GMs/S (50%) had good coulombic efficiency and cycling performance (Fig. 8f and g). After the first few-cycle unstable shuttle effect, battery performance stabilized. After 210 cycles at 1 C, GMs/S (50%) cathode retained 80% of reversible capacity from 592 mA h g−1 to 474 mA h g−1. The specific capacity dropped to 225 mA h g−1 after 2000 discharge-charge cycles. However, the GMs/S cathode battery's 99.7% average coulomb efficiency after 2000 cycles is remarkable. The Li-S battery's rate performance using microcrystalline graphite minerals/S (50%) as the cathode was shown in Fig. 8(e and f). The silicate surface covering's a good impact on Li-sulfur battery reversibility may be confirmed by graphite mineral/99.2% S's average coulomb efficiency after 120 cycles. Utilizing interlayer and ion-selecting membranes is a strategy to improve Li+ ion transport by protecting the anode and checking the polysulfide shuttle. Xu et al. [122] designed yolk-shell nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks embedded with heterostructures ZnSe-CoSe2 (ZnSe-CoSe2@NC), working as “two-in-one” hosts for both the sulfur cathode and lithium anode protection. As an anode host, thein situformed Li2Se phase contributes to the Li+ transfer. Co and Zn guide a homogenous growth of Li within the 3D framework, thus effectively suppressing Li dendrite growth. Meanwhile, the heterostructure ZnSe-CoSe2 endows the cathode host with superiorelectronic conductivity, strongpolysulfidechemisorption,and efficientcatalytic activityfor polysulfide redox when compared with single metal selenides. Combined with these advantages, this Li-S full cell exhibits ultralong cycle life over 1000 cycles at 2 C. Even with a high sulfur loading (6.08 mg cm−2) and lean electrolyte (4.1 µL mg−1), the full cell achieves a high areal capacity of 4.16 mA h cm−2 after 100 cycles at 0.2 C. This work not only provides a new approach for the structure design of Li-S full batteries but also improves the utilization of active electrode materials [122]. Wei et al. proposed a versatile 3D printed (3DP) framework comprising nitrogen-doped porous Ti3C2 MXene(N-pTi3C2T x ), which was competent in regulating the dual electrodes of Li-S batteries. Such a 3DP scaffold possesses hierarchical porosity, high conductivity, and ample nitrogen sites to synergize the lithiophilic-sulfiphilic feature. Serving as a dendrite inhibitor, the 3DP N-pTi3C2T x interlayer could dissipate the local current and homogenize Li deposition, accordingly, rendering a dendrite-free anode to maintain an ultralong lifespan up to 800 h at 5.0 mA cm−2/5.0 mA h cm−2. Meanwhile, the 3DPN-pTi3C2T x host enables suppressedpolysulfideshuttle and accelerated sulfur electrochemistry especially under elevated sulfur loadings. Thus-printed Li-S full cells (3DPN-pTi3C2T x /S||3DPN-pTi3C2T x @Li) can continuously operate over 250 cycles at a sulfur loading of 7.56 mg cm−2, accompanied by a capacity decay of 0.06% per cycle. More impressively, an ultimate capacity of 8.47 mAh cm−2 is harvested after 60 cycles at 12.02 mg cm−2 [123]. Lu et al. demonstrated a Li3PS4 based protective layer on the surface of lithium metal by a spontaneous and rapid reaction between Li metal and a THFsolution of P2S5/S. The protective layer exhibits outstanding stability and compatibility against electrolyte components. It also contributed to a stable plating and stripping process during cycling. The layer could suppress the corrosion from the shuttle effect and the parasitical reaction from the lithium salt in Li-S batteries. The lithium-sulfur batteries exhibit a specific capacity of 840 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.3C with average Coulombic efficiency of 90.1% without LiNO3 additives in the electrolyte [124]. Qian et al. constructed tri-layer GPEs of PVdF/PMMA/PVdF as separators for Li-S cells. The outer porous PVDF layer promoted Li+ transfer by absorbing ether electrolytes largely, while the inner solid PMMA layer functioned as a trapping film of polysulfides due to its good compatibility with ether electrolytes. As a result, the initial capacity of the fabricated cells was enhanced to 1711.8 mA h g−1 and the capacity retention was improved to 66.9% after 50 cycles [125]. An electrolyte is the heart of the Li-S battery system, and its stability and properties determine the overall surface discharge products and cell chemistry performance. Chen et al. developed a polymer-in-salt solid polymer electrolyte membrane with the bi-grafted polysiloxane copolymer LiTFSI and PVDF. The Li-S batteries with this composite electrolyte exhibited a very high ionic conductivity of 7.8 × 10−4 Scm−1 at ambient temperature, which is higher than the normally studied PEO-based APE and competitive with inorganic oxide systems [126]. Kim et al. [127] prepared a (1-propyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(trifluoromethysulfonyl) imide) PMImTFSI-based hybrid gel polymer electrolyte (ILGPE) using PVDF-HFP polymer as the matrix doped with SiO2 nanoparticles and added LITFSI/PMImTFSI in the matrix. The PMImTFSI can improve charge carrier mobility because of its low ion pairing. It could also decrease the dissolution of sulfur by forming the SEI layer. As a result, the ILGPE indicated an ionic conductivity of 1.1 × 10−3 S cm−1 and a high oxidation potential (>5.0 V vs. Li/Li+). The cell possessing ILGPE presented an improved electrochemical property [127,128]. Xu et al. reported an extremely high-rate Li-S battery with a hybrid electrolyte. Hybrid electrolytes consist of sulfide solid electrolyte (SSE) and liquid electrolyte (LE), where SSE functions as a barrier for suppressing polysulfide shuttling and lithium dendrite growth while LE works as fast Li+ transport media. In their work, Li10SnP2S12 membranes, with a ceramic-like dense structure, provide a rigid barrier for preventing polysulfide shuttling and lithium dendrite growth. Meanwhile, its high ionic conductivity of 3.33 × 10−3 S cm−1 (25 °C), accompanied by good wetting and Li+ transport abilities of LE, renders the hybrid electrolyte system an excellent Li+ dynamic property. Consequently, the Li-S batteries fabricated with this SSE-based hybrid electrolyte system can operate at an extremely high charge/discharge rate. At a rate of 5 C (7.10 mA cm−2), the batteries show an initial discharge capacity of 659.4 mA h g−1, maintain at 471.4 mA h g−1 and 413.3 mA h g−1 after 50 and 100 cycles, showing capacity retention of 71.53% and 62.67%, respectively [129]. A dendrite-free morphology, superior ion-dynamics at the electrode/electrolyte interface and high lithium utilization during cycling are essential for the long-term durability of LMBs [130]. Li-S batteries represent one of the most promising technologies for sustainable and large-scale electrical energy storage. Despite the tremendous efforts to improve the performance of Li-S batteries, their applications are still hindered by the multistep and complex Li-S redox processes, low cycle life and capacity, agglomeration of sulfur, volumetric expansion of the cathode, poor electric conductivity, and shuttle effect [131-133]. In order to address these issues, further research on Li-S batteries must focus on using a highly ordered conductive mesoporous carbon framework, which avoids S agglomeration, increases the contact surface, and improves the conductivity of the electrodes. The addition of heteroatoms will be a good approach to lessen the shuttle effect by forming chemical bonds [134]. The use of novel cathode designs, usually based on sulphur and carbon, such as porous carbon, carbon spheres, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), graphene, graphene oxides, and their hybrids in sulfur composite cathodes could address the low electrical conductivity of the sulfur cathode and the volumetric expansion/shrinkage during the lithiation/delithiation processes. The rational design and change of cathode surface chemistry, lithium anode protection, separator functionalization, and electrolyte additive optimization are additional approaches to enhance the performance of Li-S batteries [135]. Researchers from the areas of electrochemistry, electrochemical catalysis, theoretical simulations/calculations, and nanoscience need to come forward to make further advances in Li-S batteries [136]. 3.3 Li-O2 (Li-Air) battery Rechargeable lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries, also known as Li-air batteries, have a theoretical energy density that is much greater than that of Li-ion batteries (3500 W h kg−1) and are thus anticipated to be one of the most competitive replacements for LIBs. In comparison to the standard LIB, the mass- and volume-specific energy densities based on lithium and oxygen are, respectively, around 10 times and 3 times greater [137]. With driving ranges equivalent to those of gasoline-powered cars, this battery has ambitious curiosity in whether similar batteries may be produced to power electric vehicles. As a source of power for laptops, distant sensors, and robotic applications, Li-O2 batteries may also be crucial in other contexts [138]. The concept that oxygen from the air can be readily used forms the basis for most of the studies on LABs [139]. A rechargeable Li-O2 battery was first presented by Abraham et al. in 1996. It consisted of a carbon composite electrode i.e. a cathode made of carbon-based air to which O2 is added from the surrounding, a Li+ conductive organic polymer electrolyte membrane, and a Li metal anode [140]. The schematic of Li-O2 is shown in Fig. 9 . Li-O2 batteries may be broken down into many different types depending on the electrolyte used in their production [142]. (i) Non-aqueous electrolytes (ii) Aqueous electrolytes (iii) Solid state electrolytes (iv) Hybrid electrolytes (Combination of (i) & (ii) or (iii)) In order to advance Li-O2 batteries for real-world use, it will be necessary to address the benefits and drawbacks of all four battery systems. Discharge occurs when an anode made of Li metal is oxidised to Li+ and emits electrons, while Oxygen from the atmosphere is reduced at the surface of a catalytic air electrode to generate an oxide or peroxide ion, which subsequently combines with cationic species in the electrolyte (Oxygen reduction reaction, ORR). Li+ in the electrolyte is converted to metallic Li at the anode during the charge, while Li2O2 is electrochemically broken down at the cathode to produce oxygen (oxygen evolution reaction, OER), and Li+ [143-145]. Following are the electrochemical reactions taking place in a non-aqueous Li-O2 battery [146]. Anode: 2Li ↔ 2Li+ + 2 e− (E a = −3.05 V) Cathode: 2Li+ + O2 + 2 e− ↔ Li2O2 (E c = −0.09 V) Total: 2Li + O2 ↔ Li2O2 (E ocv = 2.96 V vs. Li/Li+) Current Li-O2 batteries have a number of drawbacks that limit their usefulness, including limited capacity and rate capability, poor round-trip efficiency, and short cycle life. Most of these problems originate from the slow and non-sustainable discharge and charge processes at lithium and oxygen electrodes [145]. To address the aforementioned issues, numerous researchers focused their research on discovering novel Li-O2 battery materials.
