Carbon-based materials, metal-based materials, inorganics, redox mediators, and their composites are among the electrode options for Li-O2 batteries. Doping carbon with pure Au, Ni, and Al results in a highly functional material with a long lifetime that is also lightweight, conductive, inexpensive and has a high surface area [139]. Jing et al. reported a three-dimensional Co and N co-doped biochar made from wood in a molten salt medium as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries. The fabricated positive electrode for lithium-air batteries could offer high specific capacity (discharge specific capacity is 9.44 mA h cm−2 under the condition of a current density of 0.05 mA cm−2) and good cycle stability (under the limited capacity of 0.5 mA h cm−2, it can be cycled 113 times) [147]. Through the use of a colloidal-micro emulsion technique, Xiao's team successfully produced a new air electrode made of hierarchically porous graphene. Because of its unusual porous structure, which consists of macropores to facilitate quick O2 diffusion and mesopores for a high density of creation, an air cathode made using these graphene sheets has an extraordinarily high capacity (15000 mA h g−1) with a C/O ratio of 14 [148]. A reversible and high-rate Li-O2 battery with a capacity retention of 95% after 100 cycles was created by Peng et al. by employing a nano porous gold electrode (NPG) as the cathode and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as the electrolyte [149]. The battery developed by Lim et al., which used LiI as a soluble catalyst, had a charge overpotential of 0.25 V, discharged at a depth of 1000 mA h g−1 at a current density of 2000 mA g−1, and operated reliably for more than 900 cycles [150]. The use of manganese (Mn)-based oxides and their composites as cathodic catalyst materials in Li-O2 batteries has been shown in certain studies to increase ORR and OER activities, decrease charge/discharge overpotential, and enhance the cycle stability [151]. The use of a metallic Li anode, which results in poor coulombic efficiency and safety concerns, has slowed the widespread adoption of Li-O2 batteries. For this reason, it is crucial to achieving the high energy density of Li-O2 batteries by discovering substitutes for metallic Li anodes [152]. Lökçü and Anik (2021) employed Li-O2 batteries with anodes made of a lithium silicide-based alloy. Both Li22Si5 and Li13Si4 alloys were produced by mechanical alloying. In order to create the cathodes, 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidone was mixed with CNTs and poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) (80:20 wt%) (NMP). The electrolyte utilised was LiTFSI (1 M) dissolved in DME:EC (95:5 vol%) solvent. This battery has a specific energy density of 1840 W h kg−1, a capacity of 800 mA h g−1 and a current density of 100 mA g−1. Its operating voltage is around 2.3 V. Initial discharge and charge capabilities of 1583 and 1474 mA h g−1 for Li22Si5 alloy and 1220 and 1122 mA h g−1 for Li13Si4 alloy is provided. It has been shown that the Li22Si5 alloy has good electrochemical performance [152]. In another work, Lee et al. reported using anodic TiO2 nanotubes in place of the Li electrode in Li-O2. The anodization approach was used to create a TiO2 nanotube coating, and it does not call for the use of any binders or conducting elements. With the help of LiCoO2 cathodes, amorphous and anatase TiO2 nanotube films were fabricated. The TiO2/LiCoO2 system operates in Li-O2 battery mode up to 3 V in an oxygen-rich environment [153]. To create the Li-O2 battery, the researchers used solid, liquid, and gel-based electrolytes. The oxygen electrode in a glycol electrolyte was used in the Li-O2 battery that Jung et al. demonstrated. There was an investigation on the oxygen electrochemical process in lithium batteries including a tetra(ethylene) glycol dimethyl ether-lithium triflate (TEGDME- LiCF3SO3) electrolyte. They exhibit a lithium-air battery that can run for a long time and has rates and capacities of up to 5,000 mA h g−1 and 3 A g−1, respectively [154]. In order to overcome drawbacks like fast Li metal anode degradation andorganic liquid electrolyte evaporation, Zou et al. built an oxygen-permeable silica-aerogel-reinforced polydimethylsiloxane external membrane (OPSP). The highly flexible OPSP's water-/electrolyte-proof, O2-permeable, high thermotolerance, and transparent qualities enable stable cycling of coin-type and flexible Li-O2 batteries under challenging circumstances like those involving a highly volatile DMSO electrolyte (for over 660 hours), a humid air (O2) atmosphere (for over 700 h), or situations involving air (O2)-saturated liquid water (over 25 h) [155]. Wang et al. developed high-performance lithium-O2 batteries that can function under ambient conditions by polymerizing the electrolyte on a lithiophilic anode. As the anode and electrolyte of a Li –O2 battery, a Li-coated polythiophene-derived (S-doped) carbon fiber-based electrode (Li/SC) and solvent-based polymer electrolyte (DES-PE) are used. The excellent lithiophilicity and stability of the SC skeleton prevent the production of dendritic Li and, hence, limit the deterioration of the electrode structure with repeated cycling. In addition to its ionic conductivity (1.19 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 30 °C), broad electrochemical window (5.0 V), no-leakage, and good interfacial compatibility, DES-PE may be combined with a SC framework to massively reduce down on Li passivation caused by air. Thus, a Li-O2 battery based on DES-PE@Li/SC could display exceptionally high-performance characteristics, including a capacity of 15,310 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, high-capacity retention even under high-current (11,896 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1), and an exceptionally long cycle life of up to 300 cycles at a constant capacity [156]. Li-O2 batteries are a class of extremely high energy–density chemical power sources that have the potential to be useful in a variety of applications, from electric cars to portable devices. These batteries suffer from multiple challenges such as limited capacity, rate capability, corrosion of the Li-metal anode, formation of lithium dendrites, flammability of organic liquid electrolytes, poor round-trip efficiency, and short cycle life [155]. To solve these challenges, future research should focus on understanding Li-air battery electrochemistry; development of a lithium protective layer to reduce dendrite growth; electrolyte additives to promote intercalation in porous carbon cathodes without discharge products or ambient gases; development of a novel catalyst for extended cycle life, efficiency, and redox control [142]. The disparities between the scientific results for pouch cells and coin cells at the device level should be addressed [157]. 3.4 Li-CO2 battery A lithium-carbon dioxide (Li-CO2) battery offers an efficient and viable method for simultaneously producing electrical energy and CO2 absorption [158]. Due to their high energy density (1876 W h kg−1), relatively high discharge plateau of 2.8 V, and environmental friendliness by trapping CO2, Li-CO2 batteries are thought to be the best option for wearable electronics[159,160]. Furthermore, it has vital uses in undersea environments and on Mars, where the atmosphere is 96% CO2 gas [6]. The following benefits of Li-CO2 batteries over Li-O2 batteries include: (1) Compared to O2, CO2 gas is simpler to store and compress. (2) CO2 is easier to consume at the cathode during discharge because CO2 is 50 times more soluble in organic solvents than O2. (3) Li-CO2 batteries have the ability to both reduce energy shortages and consume greenhouse gases [161]. A metal Li anode, an organic electrolyte-filled separator, a porous CO2 cathode with conductive additives, a binder, and a catalyst make up a Li-CO2 battery. The Li metal anode loses electrons during the discharge process to generate Li+, which disintegrates into the electrolyte, and the Li+ ions of the electrolyte migrate to the CO2 cathode under the driving force of potential difference. Dissolved CO2 molecules at the cathode/electrolyte interface pick up electrons from the cathode and react with Li+ to create discharge products of Li2CO3 and carbon species. Li-CO2 battery's electrochemical reactions during discharge/charge are as follows [162]. Discharge: 4Li+ + 3 CO2 + 4e− →2 Li2CO3 + C Charge: 2 Li2CO3 + C → 4Li+ + 3CO2 + 4e− According to reports, the Li-CO2 battery's steady functioning depends on two reactions: the CO2 evolution reaction (CDER) during the charging phase and the CO2 reduction reaction (CDRR) during the discharging process [163]. The ultimate discharge product in this battery is Li2CO3 from either the CO2/O2 combination or pure CO2 as theworking gas [164]. Li2CO3, however, has greater stability than Li2O2 [165]. A schematic illustration of the Li-CO2 battery is shown in Fig. 10 . There are several reports on Li-CO2 batteries. In 2011, Takechi et al. published the first report on the primary Li-O2/CO2 battery [167]. The first rechargeable pure Li/CO2 battery type with Li2CO3 as its primary by-product was described by Liu et al. [168,169]. In addition, Lim et al. developed a rechargeable Li-CO2/O2 battery that successfully achieved reversible discharge/charge in the DMSO-based electrolyte [170]. In a Li-CO2 battery, a “thermal trigger” zone was discovered between 40 and 60 °C where the discharge potential was discovered to vary [164]. According to a number of other studies, a Li-CO2 battery with pure CO2 gas and a moderate temperature may achieve a high discharge capacity of 2500 mA h g−1. With a higher temperature, Li2CO3 dissolves more readily in the electrolyte and deposits less on the electrode. Additionally, it lowers the transport barrier at the cathode-electrolyte interface [171]. In a Li-CO2 cell, the material employed for the anode has the greatest impact on the electrochemistry of the cell. The most popular anode material is lithium because it has the lowest standard hydrogen potential (−3.04 V) and the largest theoretical capacity (3860 mA h g−1) [172]. Another finding from Qiu's research team is that the Li-CO2 battery's cycle stability greatly depends on the stability of the lithium anode [173]. With the use of a porous electrode and electrolytes based on ethers, Qiu's research team investigated the effects of CO2 on the Li metal anode. The fabrication of stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layers and the protection of the Li metal anode against fast consumption were both facilitated by an adequate CO2 concentration. By kinetically controlling Li+ ion solvation and desolvation, Li+ transport through the film, and the mechanical stability of the SEI during Li deposition and dissolution, the composition and structure of the SEI formed at the Li metal-electrolyte interface are essential for the reversibility of the stripping and plating processes. The surface morphology and structure of the Li metal electrode, the composition of the electrolyte, and the presence of natural surface films, residues, or synthetic coatings all affect the composition and structure. The Li-CO2 battery using Li metal could achieve coulombic efficiency of 99.0% after 200 cycles at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2 [173]. Zhang et al. layering Li with Li-ethylenediamine (LE), which was then used to prepare a tetraglyme-based polymer electrolyte (TPE). The authors report that interfacial impedance and dendrite formation may be controlled by the uniform LE layer. A high discharge capacity of 22873 mA h g−1 is exhibited by the Li-CO2 battery employing LE-Li/TPE. Unlike Li/liquid electrolyte-based Li-CO2 batteries, this cell can function stably for 104 cycles with a tiny overpotential of 1.9 V [174]. The electrolyte, a crucial part of the Li-CO2 battery, has a big impact on how well the battery performs electrochemically. There are particular criteria that must be met while choosing appropriate electrolytes to create a thorough link between the discharge performance and CO2 transport qualities [175]. Liquid electrolytes in conjunction with porous carbon electrodes are now frequently employed in Li-CO2 batteries. However, the use of liquid electrolytes is dangerous and can lead to the electrolyte's breakdown; they have a limited reversible capacity and a short cycle life. According to studies, polymer electrolytes (PE) are recommended over liquid electrolytes since they increase the battery's performance metrics while also increasing the battery's safety. For improved interface stability and to prevent side reactions, PE may also separate the Li anode and CO2 [176]. Several studies have also been made about the use of organic electrolytes, such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), in Li-CO2 batteries [164]. The most popular electrolytes for Li-CO2 batteries are those based on tetra ethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME), which operate with a Li anode in a chemically stable manner and have a high oxidation potential at a relatively low cost. Amazingly, the Li-CO2 battery with gel polymer electrolyte has a very high discharge capacity, a low overpotential, and excellent cycle life, which may open up a new route for the development of high-performance Li-CO2 batteries. For these batteries, the quest for an electrolyte with a broad operating temperature range will be a focus of study [177]. With the use of ultraviolet (UV) curable technology, Li's team initially created a small and thermally stable GPE with an ionic conductivity of 0.5 mS cm. At 50 mA g−1, the GPE-based Li-CO2 battery discharged at a rate of 8536 mA h g−1, and at 500 mA g−1, it discharged at a rate of 2581 mA h g−1. Recently, it was shown that an all-solid-state Li-CO2 battery including a RuO2-single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) composite cathode and NASICON-type ceramic inorganic electrolyte (Li1.5A10.5Ge1.5(PO4)3 (LAGP)) could function across a broad range of temperatures and current densities. The discharge and charge capabilities at 60 °C were 2499 and 2137 mA h g−1, respectively [169]. By using a straightforward UV curing technique forthe electrolyte, Guo et al. created a GPE that contained 0.0025 M dinuclear cobalt phthalocyanine (Bi-CoPc-GPE). Outstanding ionic conductivity (0.86 ms cm−1), good protection for Li anodes, and excellent leak-proof performance are all features of Bi-CoPc-GPE [178]. Designing a powerful cathode catalyst that can enhance the kinetics of the CO2 reduction reaction (CRR) and CO2 evolution reaction (CER) as well as the breakdown of the primary discharge product (Li2CO3) is essential. Numerous recent studies have developed a number of very effective cathode catalysts to address the slurry reaction kinetics issue in Li-CO2 batteries [174]. In order to create a highly effective 3D free-standing cathode for Li-CO2 batteries, Liang et al. synthesised NiFe@NC-functionalized N-doped carbon nanotubes from the biomass.The Li-CO2 battery with a NiFe@NC/PPC cathode demonstrates a superior discharge capacity of 6.8 mA h cm−2 and can withstand 109 cycles with a cut-off capacity of 0.25 mA h cm−2 at a current density of 0.05 mA cm−2. Overall, this work offers a potential method for producing low-cost, environmentally friendly cathodes to enhance the performance of Li-CO2 batteries [179]. An innovative primary Li-CO2 battery with a blended conductive carbon cathode is proposed by Xu et al. At moderate temperatures, the assembled battery has a high discharge capacity of around 2500 mA h g−1. The discharge capacity is over one thousand times greater at 100 °C than it is at 40 °C [171]. The usage of Ketjen Black cathode in Li-CO2 batteries could deliver discharging specific capacity of 1032 mA h g−1 [168]. In order to develop a cathode for Li-CO2 batteries without a binder, Zhao et al. studied a Ru nanosheet catalyst supported by three-dimensional nickel foam. In order to create the Ru/Ni electrode for Li-CO2 batteries, the Ru nanosheets were directly formed on one side of the three-dimensional nickel foam by a galvanic replacement reaction. The Li-CO2 battery with the Ru/Ni catalytic cathode has an ultrahigh discharge capacity of 9502 mA h g−1 with a remarkable coulombic efficiency of 95.4% at the current density of 100 mA g−1. The better discharge rate performance of 3177 mA h g−1 at the current density of 500 mA g−1 is shown by the Ru/Ni catalytic cathode. Additionally, the Ru/Ni catalytic cathode-equipped cell may be safely discharged-charged for over 100 cycles, with a correspondingly low charge potential of just 4.1 V. The strong catalytic activity of the Ru nanosheets for the conversion process in the Li-CO2 batteries clearly reduces the charge overpotential [175]. A freestanding and flexible cobalt-doped CeO2/graphene aerogel cathode was created using a simple self-assembly method by Deng et al. A good electrocatalyst for the cathode of a Li-CO2 battery may be made using inexpensive 2D transition metal oxides (TMOs). The Li-CO2 battery, when used as-assembled, provides a better discharge capacity (7860 mA h g−1) and competitive cycling stability (>100 cycles). The development of a flexible Li-CO2 battery with a freestanding cathode in particular is able to provide a steady power output while being bent and folded at various angles [6]. For the first time, Zhang et al. employed graphene as the cathode material in a Li-CO2 battery and claimed a high discharge capacity of up to 14774 mA h g−1 and a stable cyclability over 20 cycles at a current density of 50 mA g−1 [180]. Zhang et al. investigated the electrochemical performance of carbon nanotube (CNT) cathodes in Li-CO2 batteries. The batteries with CNT cathodes have a cut-off capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 and can run steadily for 20 cycles at 100 mA g−1 with an initial discharge capacity of 8379 mA h g−1. Through 3D uniform deposition of discharged products, the structural advantages of CNTs considerably increase the electrochemical stability and cycle performance of Li-CO2 batteries [181]. There are several limitations of the Li-CO2 batteries, including high polarization, poor reversibility, poor cycle performance, and low Coulombic efficiency [162]. The subsequent research efforts on Li-CO2 batteries must focus on acquiring improved knowledge of the discharge-charge reaction mechanism, logical porous structures, exploring novel cathode materials, innovative design of the cathode structure, high-efficiency catalysts, exploring new electrolyte types with high stability windows, and the use of gradient porosity and a thin electrode to boost the discharge capacity [167]. 4 Developments on non-lithium battery systems Traditional Li-ion batteries are widely renowned for their extended cycle life, but the limited supply and concentration of lithium metal in certain countries have caused a rise in their price. Another problem for the development of Li-ion batteries is the limited capacity provided by the metal-oxide cathode. Consequently, Li-ion batteries may not be able to satisfy the demands of stationary storage systems [182]. So, there is a need to investigate alternative energy storage techniques to guarantee the sustainability of resources [183]. Due to this, researchers everywhere are putting in significant efforts to develop alternate rechargeable energy storage systems using technologies such as sodium, magnesium, and zinc batteries, etc [184]. An overview of the emerging other than Li-battery system is given in subsequent sub-sections. 4.1 Na-ion battery Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have received a lot of scientific attention in recent years as a possible lithium substitute that could be used for large-scale energy storage applications. With the exception of their principal ion carriers, SIBs, and LIBs have identical battery components and electrical energy storage mechanisms [185]. Like LIBs, SIBs were first investigated in the 1980 s [186]. SIBs are a promising candidate for addressing large-scale grid energy storage demands due to the widespread natural abundance and low price of sodium [187]. Natural sodium can be found in seawater and reserves in the earth's crust, and it is about 1000 times more plentiful than lithium. Within the past ten years, research on sodium-ion batteries has seen a dramatic increase in attention due to this apparent benefit [188]. In addition, carbon anodes in sodium-ion batteries have a lower irreversible capacity than those in lithium-ion batteries [189]. It has been discovered through research that higher temperatures are better for sodium batteries. Since SIBs have a long lifespan, great efficiency, and a high energy density, they can be used for load levelling applications [190]. Anode, cathode, nonaqueous or aqueous electrolyte, and separator are the basic components of a sodium-ion battery [191]. A schematic of a sodium-ion battery is shown in Fig. 11 . SIBs operate on a simple principle, and during the charging stage, oxidation happens at the cathode with the loss of an electron and the de-insertion of sodium ions. The sodium ion migrates simultaneously to the anode through the electrolyte, causing reduction at the anode with the addition of sodium, External conduction leads to the conduction of electrons to the anode. During the discharge phase, the reverse takes place [192]. The description of the reaction mechanism using O3-type NaMnO2 and alloying anode materials is given below [193,194]: Cathode: NaMnO2 ↔ Na1- x MnO2 + xNa++ xe− Anode: M + xNa+ + xe− ↔ Na x M Overall: M + NaMnO2 ↔ Na1- x MnO2 + Na x M where Na x M is a binary alloy. Graphite is the most frequent anode material in commercial LIBs because it forms a stable graphite intercalation combination with lithium (LiC6). Graphite cannot be utilized as a sodium anode because it lacks stable sodium carbon (Ns-C) compounds. Although other carbonaceous materials including carbon nano-spheres, carbon black, carbon microspheres, functionalized carbon nano-fibres, and carbon nano-tubes have been studied as anodes for research, their commercial use is still constrained by a challenging synthesis process and high manufacturing costs. Hard carbon and other non-graphitic carbon materials have also been considered as anodes for SIBs. carbon-based materials are usually doped with functional elements to increase electronic mobility, lower equivalent series resistance (ESR), improve sodium ion mobility, and augment capacitive performance. Sulfur (S), oxygen (O), phosphorus (P), boron (B), and nitrogen (N) are the most often employed heteroatom dopants. SIBs also employ non-carbonaceous anodes including metal oxides, alloys, etc. Several metal oxides, including Fe2O3, TiO2, MoO3, and Co3O4, have recently gained attention because of their potential as anode materials for SIBs. Due to its longer interlayer distance, which allowed it to accommodate more Na ions, reduced graphene oxide has also recently been used as an anode for SIBs. Although there are many other anode materials for SIBs, sulfide-based anode materials have performed well over the last decade. Only a few layered transition metal sulfides, such as (MSx; M = Mo, W, Sn, Zr, and V), have been used as anodes for SIBs to date. Other transition metal sulfides anticipated by first-principles calculations are ZrS2, MoS2, VS2, TiS2, NbS2, and CrS2. Selenides-based nano dimension anodes have been studied and are gaining popularity in recent years to address the low-rate capability and capacity fading of SIBs. Other materials often employed as anodes but confined to laboratory studies include metal alloys or antimony alloys, organic compounds, metal/carbon composites, and transition metal chalcogenides [192,193].Graphene, CNFs, CNTs, rGO, and their composites resist repetitive deformations. SIB anodes may employ these active materials. They also support high-capacity anode materials including metal dichalcogenides, phosphorous, tin, titanium oxides, etc. Nano-size high-capacity active materials entrapped in a flexible porous carbonaceous framework may provide a good flexible SIB anode. In such systems, high-capacity active material and carbon structure promote electronic and Na+ ion transport kinetics and inhibit volume expansion, pulverization, and aggregation. Pre-sodiating carbonaceous structures may improve battery capacity and cyclability. Encapsulating nano-sized active compounds inhybrid substrates comprising carbonaceous structures and extremely stretchy organic materials may provide high-capacity anodes with strong electronic conductivity and flexibility in all stretching, bending, rolling, and twisting [195]. By using an in situ hydrothermal process, Su et al. reported SnO2@graphene nanocomposites with 3D structure as anode materials for Sodium-ion batteries. The reported high reversible specific capacity of over 700 mA h g−1, outstanding cyclability, and decent high-rate performance of the nanocomposites could be attributed to their distinctive 3D architecture [196]. For the first time, α-MoO3 anode material for Sodium-ion batteries was demonstrated by Hariharan et al. High sodiation and desodiation first cycle capacities of 771 and 410 mA h g−1 were produced by MoO3. These anodes also displayed good rate performance of 100 mA h g−1 at a current density of 1.117 A g−1 and a long cyclability of over 500 cycles. By integrating the MoO3 anode with the Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode, a 1.4 V sodium-ion battery was produced [197]. As anode materials for SIBs, several carbonaceous substances, transition metal oxides/sulfides, intermetallic compounds, and organic compounds have all been thoroughly studied. However, the slow reaction kinetics caused by the high ionic size of Na+ ions (1.06 Å) still have to be addressed. Polyanionic compounds and layered transition metal oxides have become the predominant material classes, whereas Prussian blue analogues are also gaining popularity as inexpensive SIB cathodes [198]. By using a straightforward sol-gel technique, Liu et al. were able to create a brand-new Na3MnTi(PO4)2.83F0.5 (NMTPF-0.5) with a NASICON, hierarchical structure. As a result, the NMTPF-0.5 achieves the desired cycling stabilities, surpassing 500 cycles at 10 C, a high energy density of 511 W h kg−1 at 0.1 C, and an exceptional rate performance of 364 W h kg−1 at 10 C [199]. An all-organic Na-ion battery without the usage of transition metals is found in traditional electrochemical batteries as described by Deng et al. The authors utilized p-dopable polytriphenylamine as the cathode and n-type redox-active poly (anthraquinonyl sulphide) as the anode. With an output voltage of 1.8 V, this type of Na-ion battery may function well and achieve a significant specific energy of 92 W h kg−1. This battery has excellent rate capability, releasing 60% of its capacity at a rate of 16 C (3200 mA g−1), and excellent cycling stability, retaining 85% of its capacity after 500 cycles at a rate of 8 C. These properties are due to the structural flexibility and stability of the redox-active polymers [200]. Obtaining an adequate voltage window from the electrolytes requires the use of mixed ethylene carbonate (EC) and propylene carbonate (PC) solutions for the development of sodium-ion batteries. Future battery systems that promise to be safer and more ecologically friendly should use room-temperature ionic liquids and solid-state (glass or ceramic-based) based)/semi solid (gel polymer based) electrolytes [201]. A simple phase separation procedure was used by Yang et al. to create a Na-ion conducting gel polymer electrolyte based on poly (vinylidene difluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) porous membrane. It demonstrated excellent mechanical qualities, great safety, and superior electrochemical stability. At room temperature, the gel polymer electrolyte provided sodium ion conductivity of 0.60 × 10−3 S cm−1 while the commercial separator (Celgard 2730) only delivers 0.16 × 10−3 S cm−1. In comparison to the commercial separator, the gel polymer electrolyte's ionic transference number for sodium ions (t Na +) is 0.30, which is greater [202]. Zhu et al. developed a solid-state sodium ion electrolyte by mixing Na+ salts with the organic crystal succinonitrile, which has an electrochemical window of >3 V and a high ionic conductivity of 10−3 S cm−1 at ambient temperature. An all-organic Na-ion battery was built using poly(aniline/o-nitroaniline) (P(AN-NA)) cathode and poly (anthraquinonyl sulphide) (PAQS) anode based on this solid-state electrolyte. This solid-state battery performs competitively with organic solvent and provides an open circuit voltage of 2.4 V and a discharge rate of >800 mA h g−1 for Na-ion batteries [203]. In the last two decades, research on Na-ion batteries has grown significantly and is now competitive with Li-ion batteries. All investigations on Li systems have been successfully transferred to Sodium materials, and the majority of the mechanisms found to explain Li systems may also be used to explain Na systems [204]. Since sodium-ion batteries are created from less expensive, more plentiful, and less hazardous raw materials than lithium-ion batteries, they have been recognized as promising lithium-ion battery substitutes [205]. In a short amount of time, numerous cathode/anode pairs and electrolytes have been investigated, and some of them have shown promise as prospective SIB cathode/anode pairings [186]. The study of rechargeable batteries based on sodium-ion is progressing well. Further research on SIBs must focus on enhancing cycling steadiness, Coulomb efficiency, electronic/ionic conductivity, surface area at the electrolyte/electrode interface, and energy density values. At the same time, research efforts should be directed to reduce the phase transition, strain–stress, and volumetric expansion of electrodes. To enhance the electrochemical performance of SIBs, strategies like structure and morphology design, nanostructured flexible electrodes and substrates with additive- and binder-free designs, innovative conductive current collectors, carbon coating or embedding using a variety of carbon forms, element doping or substitution, biphasic/bimetallic synergy, and building active materials on different conductive substrates using in-situ growth and/or ex-situ incorporation techniques can be used. The scientific gap between sodium-ion rechargeable batteries (SIBs) and their lithium equivalents is decreasing day by day due to sustained efforts to optimize their chemistries [206-209]. 4.2 Na-S battery The sodium-sulfur battery is gaining significance since it is made from inexpensive materials, has a decent efficiency (about 90%), a high power density, a longer lifespan (4500 cycles), and an 80% discharge depth [210]. The sulfur cathode is fabricated from naturally abundant material, and it offers a high theoretical capacity of 1672 mA h g−1. When connected as an anode, sodium offers a cell voltage of more than 2 V and a reasonable discharge capacity. Consequently, it seems that sodium-based batteries have a strong chance of providing the energy needed for a variety of electrochemical applications [184]. A typical Na-Sbattery uses molten salt technology and operates at a high temperature of around 300 °C. In these batteries, solid ceramic sodium alumina serves as the electrolyte and uses molten sodium and molten sulfur as the negative and positive electrodes [211]. The Ford Motor Company pioneered the high-temperature sodium-sulfur battery in the 1960s, but the Tokyo Electric Power Company, in conjunction with NGK Insulators, created contemporary sodium sulfide technology in Japan [212]. In several nations, like Japan, the United States, the United Arab Emirates, and Italy, this technology has already been put into use [213]. During discharge, a commonly used high-temperature Na-S battery exhibits higher and lower plateau voltages of 2.075 and 1.7 V, respectively [214]. To facilitate the transport of Na ions, this battery needs a high temperature. Because of the safety risks posed by molten Na and S, as well as the high working temperature range restricts its practical applicability [215]. Due to positive reports on Na-S batteries providing high specific capacities at room temperature, RT Na-S batteries have recently attracted attention in the electrochemical energy storage field. These batteries incorporate ideas from previous experiences with Li-S batteries and conventional high-temperature Na-S batteries [184]. When it comes to market viability for applications, RT Na-S battery technology is a strong contender for forthcoming grid-size stationary storage devices where cost takes priority over energy density [182]. Anode, cathode, and a suitable Na+ conductive electrolyte are the typical components of RT- Na-S cells [182]. Fig. 12 . shows the schematic RT Na-S cell and discharge voltage profile with respect to different discharge products. When a battery is discharged, Na at the negative electrode releases electrons to the outside circuit, and Na ions move through the electrolyte to the positive electrode, where they combine with sulfur to produce sodium polysulfide. This process is reversible when a cell is charged; sodium ions return to the positive electrode when the sodium polysulfide at the positive electrode breaks down [216]. The RT Na-S battery's anode and cathode reactions can be stated as follows during charge/discharge [217,218]. Anode: Na ↔ Na+ + e− Cathode: nS + 2Na+ + 2e− ↔ Na2S n (4 ≤ n ≤ 8) Overall: S8 + 2Na+ +2e− ↔Na2S8 (2.2 V, 4 ≤ n ≤8) Na2S8 + 2Na+ +2e− ↔ 2Na2S4 (2.2–1.65 V, 4 ≤ n ≤8) Na2S4 + 2/3Na + 2/3e− ↔ 4/3Na2S3 (1.65 V) Na2S4 + 2Na + 2e− ↔ 2Na2S2 (1.65 V) Na2S2 + 2Na+ +2e− ↔2Na2S (1.65–1.2 V) During discharge at the cathode, long-chain polysulfide ions (Na2S n ) are produced. These ions are soluble in the electrolyte and diffuse to the anode via the separator. Decreased sulfides and diffused Na2S n combine to create lower-order polysulfide, which concentrates at the anode before diffusing back to the cathode and being reoxidized [219]. Due to the high level of reactivity of Na, the interaction between Na and Na2S n species seems to be more intense, and the shuttle effect is accentuated in the RT Na-S system, leading to poor efficiency and quick capacity degradation during cycling [217]. However, a number of concurrent problems, such as a significant volume change, a lack of ionic conductivity, a quick dendritic development rate, and a strong chemical reactivity, put a cap on the viability of sodium anodes [220]. Sodium-metal anodes have been used in almost all RT Na-S battery research projects. According to recent research, anodes made of Na-Sn-C alloy have better cyclability [221]. Lead, tin, and antimony, which alloy sodium, have high specific capacities of up to 847 mA h g−1. However, these materials expand 200%–300% during sodiation, so a theoretically generated SEI would certainly degrade with cycling. Anode materials like carbon may absorb sodium ions during charge, although they don't change volume more than 10%. Due to its extremely disordered structure and larger graphene sheet spacing, amorphous hard carbon is particularly attractive for sodium batteries. Unlike graphite, sodium ion intercalation is advantageous. Cointercalation in a diglyme-based electrolyte is the only known way to employ graphite. Due to their capacity to infuse sodium ions into their micropores, hard carbon does not expand during sodiation. For sodium-ion batteries, hard carbon is an anode material, but not for sodium-sulfur batteries. Based on its mass, pure carbon may collect 372 mA h g−1 and completely sodiated C6Na 282 mA h g−1. However, structure, porosity, particle size, and carbon supply may impact the optimum sodium charge into hard carbon [222]. Na metal anode’s long-term reversibility is still an important yet undiscovered area. Na metal anodes have low reversibility with repeated plating and stripping. This causes poor Coulombic efficiency and dendritic development. Dendrites may pierce the separator and short-circuit the battery, causing major safety risks [223]. For the preparation of RT Na-S fuel cell batteries, Kohl et al. developed a new combination of hard carbon anode sodium pre-loading and a customized electrolyte. To form a first solid electrolyte interface (SEI) on the anode surface, the electrochemical loading of sodium ions is carried out in a particular combination of diethyl carbonate, ethylene carbonate, and fluoroethylene carbonate electrolytes. Such anodes produce complete cells with a noticeably reduced polysulfide shuttle when combined with a porous carbon/sulfur composite cathode. A second SEI may be formed by using a Na2S/P2S5 doped tetra ethylene glycol dimethyl ether-based electrolyte throughout the whole cell, significantly lowering the polysulfide shuttle. More crucially, by adding this dissolved complexation agent to the electrolyte, the electrochemical discharge mechanisms in the cell are enhanced. This combination enables sodium-sulfur cells to operate at room temperature with high discharge capacities of up to 980 mA h g−1 sulfur and 1000 cycles with 200 mA h g−1 sulfur residual capacity [222]. However, it is discovered that the sodium anode is highly unstable at room temperature because of four reasons: (1) High chemical reactivity; (2) low ionic conductivity [11]; (3) rapid dendritic development; (4) large volume change. In the literature, there are few examples of solid electrolyte interphases that concurrently solve all 4 issues in order to allow sodium anodes to cycle at high rates. Carbon-sulfur composites with a 1D fibrous structure, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and hollow carbon sphere-sulfur (HCS-S) cathodes are used as cathodes in the Na-S battery [221]. A sugar-derived RT Na-S battery with long-term cycling reliability was described by Carter et al. They presented a RT Na-S battery built on a microporous carbon template made from sucrose. This battery can produce over 700 mA h g−1 S of reversible capacity at 0.1 C rates and can sustain 370 mA h g−1 S at ten times higher 1 C rates. Due to microporous sulfur confinement and the durability of the sodium metal anode in a glyme-based electrolyte, cycling at 1 C rates demonstrates preservation of more than 300 mA h g−1 S capacity through 1500 cycles with coulombic efficiency >98% [224]. For sulfur cathodes, Du et al. developed a three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical cathode substrate with VO2 nanoflowers grown in situ on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as the catalyst. An in situ grown VO2 nanoflower cathode catalyst on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) was used by Du et al. for developing a three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical cathode substrate for sulfur cathodes. A reversible initial capacity of 876.4 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C is achieved by rGO/VO2/S composites. Additionally, after 1000 cycles at 2 C and a lengthy cycling period, a capacity of 156.1 mA h g−1 was shown, and great cycle stability was established with just 0.07% capacity degradation per cycle [13]. In order to create a free-standing cathode, Kumar et al. used sodium polysulfide (Na2S6) catholyte as the active substance and manganese dioxide decorated carbon cloth (CC@MnO2) as an electronically-conducting substrate with a polysulfide reservoir. A remarkable capacity retention of 67% after 500 cycles and an initial reversible specific capacity of 938 mA h g−1 is obtained using this cathode. The assembled RT Na-S cell operates at an average potential of 1.82 V and provides an initial energy density (based on the mass and molecular weight of sulfur and sodium) of 946 W h kg−1. After 50 cycles, an energy density of 855 W h kg−1 is obtained, which reduces to 728 W h kg− 1 after 500 cycles [225]. After 2011, the frequently employed electrolytes have been the polymer-based gel electrolytes and liquid-phase electrolyte systems based on dimethoxymethane (DME) and/or tetra ethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) solutions combined with porous separators [221]. The ion-transport characteristic of a sodium-ion conducting polymer gel electrolyte based on poly(methyl methacrylate) and including sodium triflate salt, PMMA polymer, and tetra ethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) as solvent was studied by Singh et al. The 40-weight% TEGDME content in the optimised polymer gel electrolyte offered an RT ionic conductivity of 3.6 × 10−3 S cm−1. The reported sodium ion transport number of the flexible polymer gel electrolyte membrane was 0.37 with an electrochemical stability window of 4.4 V. The initial discharge capacity of a prototype RT Na-S battery using the enhanced electrolyte is 677 mA h g−1, and the battery exhibits a consistent open circuit voltage of 2.24 V [101]. Murugan et al. introduced sodium bis(perfluoropinacol)borate, NaB[O2C2(CF3)4]2 (Na-PPB), as a portion of the electrolyte for room-temperature (RT) sodium-sulfur batteries based on a sulfurized poly(acrylonitrile) (Na-SPAN) cathode. With 100% coulombic efficiency far over 500 cycles, it displayed good oxidation stability against a variety of current collectors and a discharge capacity of >950 mA h g−1 sulfur is obtained [226]. At room temperature, Na3PS4 glass-ceramic was used as the solid electrolyte in the all-solid-state Na-S batteries fabricated by Tanibata et al. The acetylene black conductive additive, Na3PS4 glass–ceramic electrolyte, and sulfur active material were mechanically milled to create the sulfur composite electrodes, which had a high capacity of 1100 mA h (g of S)−1 at room temperature [227]. Zhao et al. evaluated the impact of fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as an addition to a 1.0 M NaClO4-ethylene carbonate/propylene carbonate electrolyte in a RT Na-S battery with a high-surface-area carbon/sulfur composite as the cathode. The YP50F/S electrode can supply up to 1651 mA h g−1 of reversible capacity at 0.1 C when used with 1.0 M NaClO4-EC/PC electrolyte with 5 wt% FEC [228]. As a result of the reactive nature and dendritic development of sodium (Na) metal anodes, one of the major technologies for sodium (Na) metal batteries is the construction of stable electrolytes. Na salts, (co–)solvents, and electrolyte additives are a few of the several methods from the electrolyte side that have been suggested to stabilize the Na-metal-anode electrolyte interface. The content and structure of the SEI on anodes may be controlled by the breakdown of salt anions, stabilizing the anode-electrolyte interface [229]. The research and development on RT Na-S cells reveal that these cells are a promising option for energy storage applications [184].Further research on RT Na-S cells should address the fundamental issues such as the poor conductivity of elemental sulfur, significant volume change during charge-discharge cycling, serious shuttle effect, compatibility between electrodes and electrolyte, and dendritic growth at the sodium anode to bridge the wide gap existing between the theoretical and experimental electrochemical parameters [230]. Utilization of advanced sulfur-carbon cathode nano-materials, impregnating sulfur into microporous carbon materials, combining sulfur with polymer matrix, using polymer electrolyte, developing better cell configuration structures, incorporating sodium alloys, and intelligent cycling strategies will be the research considerations to overcome these difficulties and develop the next generation RT Na-S cell [184]. 4.3 Mg-ion battery Rechargeable Magnesium batteries have gained interest due to their great volumetric energy density (3833 mA h cm−3), the decent abundance of raw materials, safety, and high specific capacity of 2205 A h kg−1 [231,232]. In numerous significant families of electrolyte solutions, dendritic development is a problem that is avoided by the behavior of magnesium deposition, which prevents dendrite nucleation and growth. Mg batteries are already being developed for commercial use by Sony Corporation and the Toyota Research Institute of North America [233]. Aurbach et al. [234] constructed a prototype Mg battery utilizing an Mg anode, a Mo6S8 Chevrel phase (CP) cathode, and an organohaloaluminate salt-based electrolyte solution. This prototype device for a magnesium battery performs poorly and has a low operating voltage (1.1 V) [235]. Cathode, anode, electrolyte, and current collector are the main components of magnesium-ion batteries [236]. The anode goes through oxidation during the discharge process, and magnesium ions are also released from their intercalation. The magnesium ions that are released go to the cathode through the electrolyte and are then incorporated into the active components. At the same time as the reduction process takes place at the cathode, the chemical energy is transformed into electrical energy, and electrons will flow out of the anode via an externally linked circuit. An external voltage is provided during charging, which causes the redox processes to be reversed [237]. A schematic of a rechargeable Mg-battery with redox reaction is shown in Fig. 13 . High-performance rechargeable Mg-ion batteries still face a number of obstacles, such as the incompatibility of the anode-electrolyte-cathode system, the development of a passivated solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer, and the slow kinetics of Mg2+ ions as they travel through electrodes [238]. For Mg-ion batteries, the choice of cathode material consists of vanadium oxide, Prussian blue analogues, molybdenum sulphide, including the Chevrel phase: Mo6T8, molybdenum disulfide, MoS2, molybdenum oxide, manganese oxides, and transition metals [239]. In order to develop novel cathode materials for storing magnesium ions, Kravchyk et al. examined copper sulfide nanoparticles (CuS NPs). They demonstrated the very reversible introduction of Mg-ions into a nanostructured CuS cathode. The Mg-ion battery fabricated using these CuS NPs possesses excellent coulombic efficiency of 99.9%, great cyclic stability over 200 cycles, and high capacities of around 300 mA h g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1 (1 C). These findings not only highlight the crucial role that nanomaterials play in enhancing the kinetics of conversion processes, but they also indicate the need for using nanostructuring as a key tool in the search for novel cathodes for multivalent (Mg, Ca, Al)-ion batteries [240]. Wang et al. developed an aqueous magnesium ion battery that is rechargeable (AMIB). They developed a high voltage (1.9 V) AMIB complete cell based on the Mg ion aqueous electrolytes with a stability window of 2.0 V and coupling of two unique Mg ion host materials. Lithium vanadium phosphate, also known as Li3V2(PO4)3, has been shown to be the optimal Mg ion host cathode material due to its high working voltage and quick kinetics. A 1.9 V AMIB complete cell may achieve a high specific energy density of 68 W h kg−1, high power density of 1440 W h kg−1, and better cycling stability of 6000 cycles by linking with a non-diffusion-controlled polyimide anode (poly pyromellitic dianhydride, PPMDA). Grid-storage or renewable energy harvesting systems are two examples of large-scale applications where this high-voltage AMIB idea provides an economical and safe energy storage solution [241]. Delta-manganese dioxide (delta-MnO2) was explored by Wu et al. as a very efficient Mg2+ host material because of its structural water, which effectively screens the interaction of Mg2+ with host lattices and so enables the Mg intercalation/deintercalation. By using an electrochemically assisted technique, hierarchically porous delta-MnO2 films were created on Ti foils. The films were arrays of mesopore- and -MnO2 nanograin-built delta-MnO2 nanoflakes, as shown by electron microscopy data. High-rate performance (250 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1) and outstanding cycle performance (84% retention after 1500 cycles at 3 A g−1) of the cathode material is made possible in an aqueous electrolyte by the enhanced kinetics of Mg2+ in the host lattice [242]. The magnesium alloys and carbon-based compounds are the dominant sources under consideration for the anode part [243]. Bi nanotubes were fabricated and used by Shao et al. as a high-performance anode material for rechargeable Mg ion batteries. A hydrothermal reaction process was used to create Bi-NTs. The nanostructured Bi anode exhibits outstanding stability, high coulombic efficiency, and high reversible specific capacity (350 mA h g−1 Bi or 3430 mA h cm−3 Bi) [244]. As promising anode materials for magnesium-ion batteries, Liang et al. presented a first-principles investigation of monolayer and heterostructure antimonene. According to the findings, the monolayer has a comparatively high binding energy for Mg atoms in comparison to the heterostructure of antimonene (−0.72 eV for antimonene and −0.70 eV for the heterostructure). In addition, they demonstrated that the surface of the heterostructure is more conducive to Mg ion transport than the surface of the antimonene monolayer, and the lowest diffusion barrier is 45 meV. The capacities of antimonene-based nanostructures are found to be 735 mA h g−1 (as Mg1.67Sb), and 615 mA h g−1 (as Mg1.78SbC2.78) [245]. For rechargeable Mg-ion batteries, Singh et al. presented a high-energy–density Sn anode that demonstrated higher operating voltages and capacity. Here, the potential utilisation of simple, inexpensive high energy–density insertion-type anode materials for a Mg-ion battery system was investigated employing Sn powder films as electrodes. They could demonstrate that a Sn anode could achieve greater capacities (903 mA h g−1) and lower Mg2+ insertion/extraction voltages [246]. A novel aqueous Mg-ion battery was developed by Chen et al. by employing polyimide as the anode, Prussian blue materials as the cathode, and a 1 M MgSO4 aqueous solution as the electrolyte. When utilizing a highly unstable organic electrolyte, this aqueous battery may operate at a voltage that is closer to that of a Mg-metal battery. It also has far more stable cycling characteristics, lasting up to 5000 charge-discharge cycles with 60% capacity retention. The cost of this aqueous Mg-ion battery will also be much cheaper than that of existing aqueous battery systems due to its simple manufacture and the recyclable nature of Prussian blue and polyimide [247]. Any battery system would be incomplete without an electrolyte. For a magnesium battery, Ramesh et al. fabricated a solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) system based on PVdF-HFP and magnesium trifluoromethanesulfonate (MgTf) with concentrations ranging from 5 to 40 wt%. By comparing the magnitude of ionic conductivity, three distinct kinds of impedance spectra have been distinguished. Its trend rises approximately proportionately to the amount of magnesium salt present, and at 40% MgTf salt, it achieves its greatest ionic conductivity of 10−3 S cm−1. The rise in charge carriers and amorphous phase from low to high levels of dopant salt concentration may be responsible for this [248]. A study on a room-temperature blend polymer electrolyte (BPE) for a magnesium battery was reported by Manjuladevi et al. Using a solution-casting method using dimethylformamide (DMF) as the solvent, they have created BPE films with a 92.5PVA:7.5PAN ratio tuned for highest conductivity. The magnesium salt Mg(NO3)2 was added at 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, and 0.4 m.m.%. At room temperature, the highest conductivity 1.71 × 10–3 S cm−1 was achieved using a mixture of 92.5PVA, 7.5PAN, and 0.3 m.m.% Mg(NO3)2. The 92.5PVA:7.5PAN:0.3 m.m.% Mg(NO3)2 optimised membrane, which has a high ionic conductivity, has been applied to a primary magnesium battery, resulting in an OCV of 2.02 V. [249]. Pandey et al. used a variety of electrical and electrochemical methods to investigate the impact of micron-sized MgO particles dispersion on PVdF-HFP based magnesium-ion conducting gel polymer electrolyte. A maximum electrical conductivity of 6 × 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature (25 °C) is provided by the optimum composition with 10 wt% MgO particles. A variety of Mg (or Mg-MWCNT composite)/composite gel film/V2O5 solid-state cells were designed, and their charge-discharge properties were assessed. The cell, made of Mg-MWCNT composite, composite gel film, and V2O5 has a discharge capacity of about 175 mA h g−1 [250]. Mg-ion secondary batteries are anticipated to be an alternative to Li-ion batteries due to their low price, sufficient reduction potential (−2.356 V vs. SHE), high volumetric energy density (3832 mA h cm−3), and very safe cell operation [251]. The slow diffusion kinetics, the absence of a suitable cathode, and the difficulties with Mg metal and electrolyte compatibility may result in a low working voltage, mediocre rate performance, and unsatisfactory cycle stability of the MIBs [252]. The upcoming research on Mg-ion batteries must focus on modifying liquid electrolytes using additives, building artificial SEI, fabricating novel Mg alloys, constructing interfacial alloy layers, manufacturing 3D scaffolds, employing solid electrolytes, designing the appropriate organic-based materials with accessible redox sites, developing advanced characterisation techniques, and delving further into theoretical research [253,254]. 4.4 K-ion battery The development of new non-Li-based rechargeable battery technologies is essential due to the growing need for large-scale energy storage. K-ion batteries (KIBs) are widely used due to their natural abundance and availability [255]. The low standard reduction potential of K/K+ (2.93 V vs. SHE) and quick ion transport kinetics in the electrolytes of KIBs lead to cheap pricing per kW h, high energy density, and a range of other advantages [256]. Since Li and K are both present in the alkali group of the periodic table, and since Li and K have appealing chemical characteristics together, it makes sense to apply LIB methods to KIBs. As a shuttle carrier for energy storage batteries in the “rocking chair” style, K offers a number of characteristics that might be advantageous. These advantages of K significantly influence the voltage potential in KIBs, as shown by the fact that KIBs have a higher voltage potential than SIBs and have better conductivity in K-based electrolytes [257]. Eftekhari reported a K secondary cell that used a K anode and a Prussian-blue-based cathode. Nevertheless, because of the safety issues with the K metal, research on KIBs has been stagnant for a long time [258]. Similar to other battery systems, the cathode, anode, and electrolyte are the three main parts of a KIB. The separator and current collector are additional working parts. The working principle of KIB is shown in Fig. 14 and explained below. During charging, K ions are drawn out of the cathode and move from there via the electrolyte to the anode, while an equivalent amount of electrons also move in the other direction through an external circuit. During the discharge process, the reverse process happens [260]. The following are the reactions of the chemical processes occurring at the graphite anode and the potassium-containing layered metal oxide KMO2 cathode, where M represents Mn, Co, or Ni [261]. Cathode: KMO2 ↔ K1- x MO2 + x K+ + x e− Anode: x K+ + 8 C + x e− ↔ K x C8 All: KMO2 + 8 C ↔ K1- x MO2 + K x C8 The two most important problems associated with K-ion batteries are poor interfacial stability and low coulombic efficiency. The development of K-ion batteries is also constrained by the absence of appropriate electrolyte alternatives and thorough characterization [262]. For the anodes of K-ion batteries, graphite, various carbon materials, such as soft carbon, hard carbon microspheres, hard-soft composites, carbon nanofibers, and F, N, P, and O-doped, K alloys, are used. Undoped graphene is also used [263]. Hard carbon (HC) is recognized as a good choice foranode for K-ion batteries owing to its high electrical conductivity, great structural stability, simple synthetic procedure, and cheap manufacturing cost [264]. By optimising the solvent, Qiao et al. reported the synthesis of porous SnP2O7 composite, which is considered a high-rate and long-life anode material for potassium-ion batteries. This study used solvothermal and calcination techniques to create a porous SnP2O7 filled with rGO (P-SPO/rGO) composite material with alloying and conversion processes. It has a high reversible capacity of 351.5 mA h g−1, a long cycle life, and outstanding rate performance because of the porous construction [265]. Wu et al. created a simple scaling-up technique for the mass manufacture of micro-sized SnSb/C composites for improved performance potassium-ion batteries (KIBs). The electrode produced a high capacity of 419 mA h g−1 with excellent capacity retention of 84.3% at 50 mA h g−1 after 600 cycles and 340 mA h g−1 with 80.7% capacity retention for 800 cycles at 1000 mA h g1 by coupling the optimal binder (CMC + PAA) and electrolyte (3 M KFSI in DME). This exceptional cyclability is attributed to the interaction between the cross-linked binder's mechanical strength and the stable SEI layers derived from the electrolyte, and it confirms the potential use of SnSb/C composite as an exceptional alternative anode material for KIBs [266]. Du et al. developed a very stable SnTe nanoparticle-encrusted multilayer graphene anode for potassium-ion batteries. The layered structures of SnTe and MGS provide additional reaction sites for the diffusion behaviour. SnTe/MGS also provides a high initial reversible capacity of 345.7 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1, notable long-term stability of 279.4 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 after 1000 cycles, and desirable rate performance of 180.1 mA h g−1 at 2.0 A g−1 when used as an anode for KIBs [267]. Improvements to the cycling performance of graphite for KIBs have been suggested, including increasing the interlayer distance of graphite (i.e., element doping and creating enlarged graphite and/or adjusting the components of electrolytes (i.e., salts, solvents, and additives) [268,269]. N-doped porous carbon nanosheets exhibit very stable K+ storage because their plentiful edge-N promotes surface-driven pseudocapacitive activity that lessens structural deterioration. Oxygen electrocatalysis is increased by the plasma-etched carbon cloth (P-CC) with flaws and doping [270]. The use of carbon nanofibers with iron phosphide nanoparticles (Fe2P-CNFs) as the anode for a potassium-ion battery was described by Sun et al. Electrospinning, phosphorylation, and carbonization are effective methods for creating Fe2P-CNFs. The resulting Fe2P-CNFs, which contain internal Fe2P nanoparticles with high electronic conductivity (3.3 × 10−1 S cm−1, Fe2P single crystal), can accelerate electron transfer while simultaneously producing a large number of defects for K-ion storage. Furthermore, the amorphous characteristics of CNFs can offer sufficient sites or voids for more K-ions. Accordingly, Fe2P-CNFs provide excellent reversible capacity (379.5 mA h g−1), high-rate capability, and longer cycle lifespan when used as a self-supporting anode for KIBs (179.6 mA h g−1 over 2000 cycles at 2000 mA g−1) [271]. Yang et al. studied graphene-loaded phosphate nano bundles based on bismuth (Bi) and antimony (Sb) as a preferable anode for potassium-ion batteries. The Bi and Sb based (in a ratio of 47:53) phosphate nano bundles could demonstrate promising voltage plateaus and give a favourable cycling performance for 400 cycles under 500 mA g−1. They achieve a gravimetric capacity of 288 mA h g−1 with a remarkable capacity of 99%. The cell could achieve a recognised capacity of 372 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 [272]. Lin et al. reported phosphorous carbide (PC5) monolayer as a promising anode candidate for KIBs. The PC5 monolayer exhibits very good electrical conductivity, which ensures rapid electronic transport during cycling. Moreover, the potassium diffusion barrier of PC5 is 0.18 eV, implying high ionic mobility. The PC5 monolayer has a strong affinity for potassium and a small volume expansion (0.57%) during the intercalation process, which could prevent the formation of metallic dendrites and improve cycle life. Remarkably, the specific capacity of PC5 is as high as 835.18 mA h g−1, superior to many reported 2D materials [273]. As a promising KIBs anode, Wang et al. produced hierarchical porous N-doped carbon microspheres embedded with nano-Sb (Sb@HPNC), manufactured using an easy and controlled method. In comparison to the bulk Sb electrode, the Sb@HPNC anode demonstrates superior rate capability (a reversible capacity of 501 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.1 A g−1) and an amazing capacity of 507 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.1 A g−1 over 100 cycles. Meanwhile, over 700 cycles, Sb@HPNC exhibits remarkable long-cycle stability with 262 mA h g−1 at 1.0 A g−1 [274]. Prussian blue analogues (PBAs), polyanionic compounds, organic materials, and layered transition-metal oxides have been reported as positive electrode (cathode) materials for these batteries[275]. As the cathode for a potassium-ion battery, Liu et al. developed a three-dimensional amorphous carbon network adapted from the plum pudding model. KVPO4F particles are uniformly coated in an amorphous carbon layer and connected by crosslinked large area carbon sheets in the composite. The KVPO4F@3DC composite, which serves as the cathode for KIBs, has a super-high discharge capacity of 102.96 mA h g−1 at 20 mA g−1 and a high average working voltage of 4.10 V. Outstanding long-cycle stability is achieved with a capacity retention of 85.4% after 550 cycles at 500 mA g−1. Additionally, after 100 cycles, it maintains 83.6% of its original capacity at 50 mA g−1 [276]. Jiang et al. proposed an aqueous K-ion battery (AKIB) system made up of an organic 3,4,9,10-perylene tetra carboxylic diimide anode, a 22 M KCF3SO3 water-in-salt electrolyte, and a Fe-substituted Mn-rich Prussian blue K x [Fe(CN)6] w .zH2O cathode.Due to Fe substitution's reduction of phase transitions, the cathode maintains 70% of its capacity at 1000 C and has a lifespan of over 10,000 cycles. The AKIB operates efficiently at rates of 0.1–20 C and over a broad temperature range (20 to 60 °C) and has a high energy density of 80 W h kg−1 [277]. Gao et al. develop Fe/Mn coexistent Prussian blue analogues (FeMnHCF) for the cathode of a potassium-ion battery. Fe0.5Mn0.5HCF displays a high discharge voltage (3.82 V vs. K+/K) and achieves a prolonged cycle life (over 600 cycles) in an ester electrolyte. The findings show that the coexisting coordinated structure enhances the redox potential of N-coordinated iron as well as the capacity contribution at high voltage (above 3.5 V) [278]. Typically,theelectrolyteisacombinationoforganicsolventsandKsaltsin a solution [279]. For the first time, Liu et al. reported using a potassium-ion battery (KIB) with an electrolyte comprising 1.5 M KFSI (potassium(bis)-fluorosulfonylimide) dissolved in a combination of propylene carbonate (PC), tetraethoxy-glyoxal (TEG), and vinyl-ethylene carbonate (VEC). They demonstrated that this electrolyte has strong thermal stability, excellent transport characteristics, and wide electrochemical stability. When utilised in PC/TEG, graphite and Prussian White (PW) electrodes exhibit good capacity, even at high C-rates, and remarkable cycle stability when 1.5 M KFSI is employed. It is possible to effectively integrate these electrodes in a KIB that exhibits excellent efficiency and good stability for more than 500 cycles [280]. The popularity of KIBs has increased recently as a result of high cell voltages, improved ionic mobility, technical resemblance to well-established Li-ion batteries, cheap cost, and an abundance of potassium [281]. Further research on KIB must address the challenges such as low coulombic efficiency, capacity fading, poor energy density, and inadequate cyclability. As far as anodes for KIBs are concerned, the traditional graphite anode for LIBs is no longer relevant for KIBs due to the radius of K+ being almost twice that of Li+ [282]. Alloying and intercalated nano-sized anodes will be a better choice among the available anode chemistries since they can offer high voltages and avoid significant volume expansion. The use of particle nanosizing or morphological optimization may be able to reduce these problems. Building a stable SEI layer on the electrode materials during the plating and stripping of K can be a promising approach to enhancing the cycle life of KIBs [255]. In a broad range of cathode chemistries, replacing the K-layered oxides with polyanionic substances or analogues of Prussian blue with multielectron redox reactions may provide superior electrochemistry [263]. The anode dendrite development has been actively suppressed via several attempts, and various methods, such as electrode design, current collector construction, and interface engineering, have been suggested. The construction of 3D metal electrodes and metal/carbon composite anodes is one practical method for suppressing dendrites. Additionally, electrode design gives enough space for the volume change of metallic anodes in comparison to interfacial modification, which not only reduces polarization but also enhances charge transfer kinetics [283]. The practical application of KIBs would be made possible by further advancements in energy density, cyclability, and high-power operation by adopting the above-cited approaches [275]. 4.5 Al-ion battery In a quest to realise metal battery systems, aluminium is a clear choice to take into consideration because of its light weight, safety, easy availability, and high energy density through three-electron transfer [284]. Al-based batteries are appealing options due to their impressive theoretical specific energy (8100 W h kg−1), inexpensive price, and negative electrode potential (−1.66 V vs. NHE) [22]. Al-based batteries are anticipated to be safer than lithium-based batteries [284]. Al-ion batteries (AIBs) have been regarded as one of the most promising energy storage technologies because of their very large volumetric capacity, high natural abundance, high level of safety, and inexpensive cost owing to the ample amount of Al. Although AIBs were originally developed in the early 1970s, they gained worldwide attention in the 2010s [285]. In 1972, Holleck and Giner of Tycho Laboratories in Massachusetts may have undertaken the first effort to build up an AIB based on the reduction of Cl2 in a vitreous carbon electrode. An Al alloy-based anode, a cathode, and an electrolyte make up a typical AIB [286], whose schematic design is in Fig. 15 . The following redox processes were postulated for the graphite/AlCl3/[EMIm]Cl/Al cell during charging and discharging: (1) 4Al2Cl7 − + 3e− ↔ Al + 7AlCl4 − (2) C n + AlCl4 − ↔ C n [AlCl4] + e− where n denotes the graphite's intercalated anions' molar ratio of carbon atoms [288]. Upon discharge, atoms from a metal anode undergo oxidation and release electrons into the external circuit. Aluminium ions, which may exchange three electrons per ion when a cell recharges, go back to the anode. The electrode material is the key component, and it primarily determines how well Al-ion batteries operate [289]. For use in Al-ion batteries, Hao et al. created an Al-anode coated in poly(vinylidene difluoride) (PVDF), which may prevent free H2O/O2 and lessen the corrosion issue. Theoretical calculations demonstrate that the observed uniform Al deposition is the result of a strong interaction between PVDF and Al3+ via the F-Al link. The PVDF-Al/K2CoFe(CN)6 cell obtains a current density of 100 mA h g−1 and coulombic efficiency of 98.2% after 400 cycles [290]. Positive electrode materials now in use are classified using two separate ideas: according to the substance (e.g. graphite, transition metals, sulfur, and polymers); and secondly, according to the structure (e.g., layer, nanowire, and nanoparticle) [291]. A highly reversible positive electrode made of a two-dimensional layered graphene/TiO2 nanosheets composite and an electrolyte made of chloroaluminate ionic liquid were used to create an AIB by Xue et al. The two primary anionic carriers in charge storage have been identified as AlCl4 and Al2Cl7. In the voltage range of 0.1–0.9 V, the AIBs have good electrochemical capabilities. The obtained discharge specific capacity is 313.2 mA h g−1 at 0.1 A g−1. Additionally, even after 100 cycles, a high specific capacity of 40.0 mA h g−1 is preserved [292]. Xing et al. reported a three-dimensional carbon-encapsulated cobalt selenide nanoparticle from metal organic frameworks as a novel aluminium ion batteries cathode that delivers a discharge capacity of 427 mA h g−1 at 1000 mA g−1 with two high discharge plateaus at 1.0 and 1.9 V (equivalent to the energy density of 424 W h kg−1). Furthermore, even at a very high current density of 5000 mA g−1, the cathode's initial discharge capacity may reach 254.8 mA h g−1, and a high capacity of 62.4 mA h g−1 is maintained after 100 cycles [293]. An essential element of the overall electrochemical performance of the AIBs device is the electrolyte, which serves as the medium for ion transport between the negative and positive electrodes [291]. AlCl3/pyridinium chloride (PC), created by Xu et al., is manufactured as the novel ionic liquid electrolyte for an aluminium-ion battery. This electrolyte, coupled with spherical graphite (SG) as the cathode, can deliver 123 mA h g−1 at a current density of 1 A g−1. After 500 cycles, it has an excellent coulombic efficiency of 97% and can achieve 101 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1. With SG cathode, AlCl3/PC electrolyte exhibits a high specific capacity, steady cycling performance, and rate capability [294]. A flexible aqueous Al-ion battery was created by Wang et al. by utilizing cellulose paper as the substrate. A lightweight and thin-film battery prototype was designed by storing the water-in-salt electrolyte within the paper and attaching or printing the electrodes on the paper surface. The battery can sustain up to 4 A g−1 of charge and discharge rates without a significant decrease in discharge capacity. The discharge plateau of 1.6–1.8 V was among the highest in recorded aqueous Al ion batteries, and it was accompanied by a high discharge specific capacity of 140 mA h g−1. Due to the water electrolysis side reaction and the subsequent drying out of the electrolyte, the faradic efficiency can reach 85% with a cycle life of 250. Paper-based Al-ion batteries can withstand different deformations such as bending, rolling, and even puncturing without losing their performance. The battery pack can provide a charge voltage of 4.3 V and a discharge plateau as high as 3–3.6 V when two single cells are linked in series, which is extremely similar to the performance of commercial Li-ion batteries [295]. Rechargeable Al-ion batteries are being investigated as potential new members of the rechargeable battery family due to their high theoretical gravimetric and volumetric capacity values. The significant obstacles in the advancement of Al-ion batteries include anode passivation and corrosion, incompatibility between electrodes and electrolytes, low specific capacity, low charge-discharge voltage plateaus, and shorter cycle life [296,297]. The upcoming research strategies to enhance the electrochemical performance of Al-ion batteries will be via designing heterostructure composite cathodes by mixing carbon-based materials, oxides, sulfides, or other open channel configurations due to the synergistic impact of each individual component or enhanced conductivity, construction of an artificial SEI layer on Al metal, fabrication of appropriate electrolytes and corrosion-resistant current collecting materials, and using quasi-solid state electrolytes and deep eutectic solvents to inhibit the hydrogen evolution process [285,288]. 4.6 Al-air battery Aluminium is the second-most plentiful metallic element, which is also the least priced, non-toxic, recyclable, and favourable to the environment [298]. Al metal has the largest theoretical volumetric capacity for energy storage at 8,046 mA h cm−3, and its theoretical specific capacity (2,981 A h kg−1) is second only to Li metal (3,861 A h kg−1) [299]. The air-breathing Al-air battery, one of the existing Al energy technologies, is promising and has a usable specific energy density as high as 700 W h kg−1. It turns chemical energy into electricity by consuming infinite amounts of oxygen in the air without transporting it [300]. Theoretically, the Al-air battery system has a high voltage (2.7 V), a high energy density (8.1 kW h kg−1), is inexpensive, and is made of reusable materials. This technology may prove to be an effective method for electric vehicles [301]. In 1962, Zaromb et al. made the first proposal for Al-air batteries [302]. As shown in Fig. 16 , the components of an aluminum-air battery include porous carbon as the cathode with catalysts, electrolyte, hydrophobic separator, and metal aluminium as the anode [303]. The following are the electrochemical processes for Al-air batteries [304]. Anodic half reaction: Al + 3 OH− →Al(OH)3 + 3 e− (potential at pH 14 –2.31 V) Cathodic half reaction: O2 + 2 H2O + 4 e− → 4 OH− (potential at pH 14 +0.40) Overall reaction: 4 Al + 3 O2 + 6 H2O → 4 Al(OH)3 (theoretical open-circuit voltage 2.71 V) However, the existing Al-air battery is plagued with a common issue known as Al self-corrosion. Numerous barriers to its practical deployment arise from this issue, including poor energy efficiency, limited shelf life, and safety issues [305]. Methods of mitigation have been offered to deal with this problem, such as negative electrode alloying, electrolyte additives, solid-state electrolytes, nonaqueous electrolytes, and draining or oil displacing the electrolyte after shutdown [306]. Anodes for Al-air batteries are made of pure aluminium and aluminium alloys. Numerous substances, including Ga, Ti, In, Zn, and Sn, have been regarded as alloying components in the fabrication of aluminium alloys [307]. To improve the efficiency of Al-air batteries, Luo et al. developed a new hybrid additive that would create a bifunctional interface layer on the anode. It contains zinc oxide (ZnO) and 4-amino-6-hydroxy-2-mercaptopyrimidine (AHMP) to prevent the self-corrosion of Al-6061 in alkaline batteries. The bulk capacity of a complete cell rises from 879 mA h g−1 (blank) to 1785 mA h g−1, and the anode utilisation rate exceeds 60% (with the hybrid additive). Surprisingly, this layer also activates the anode, increasing the discharge voltage of a full cell [308]. Wu et al. investigated the Al-0.02 Mg-0.01Sn-0.004Bi-0.003In alloy used as the anode for Al-air batteries in alkaline electrolyte. Through the use of melting and casting, the authors added Mg, In, Sn, and Bi to the aluminium alloy. For the produced alloy in the 4 M NaOH electrolyte, hydrogen evolution, self-corrosion and electrochemical performance were examined. According to a SEM study, the alloy components can have a synergistic impact and greatly lower the rate at which the aluminium anode self-corrodes. At a high discharge rate (50 mA cm−2), discharge studies demonstrate that the produced alloy can deliver capacity density and energy density of 2857.14 A h kg−1 and 4805.71 W h kg−1, respectively [309]. Recent studies have shown the potential of aligned carbon nanotubes, metal or metal oxide composites, and carbon materials for oxygen electrodes in Al-air batteries [310]. As binder-free cathodes for Al-air batteries, Liu et al. reported ultrathin Co3O4 nanosheet clusters anchored on nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes/3D graphene using chemical vapour deposition (CVD) and thermal processing on a Ni foam substrate. With a binder-free cathode made of Co3O4/NCNTs/3D graphene, the Al-air coin cell achieves an open circuit voltage of 1.52 V, a specific capacity of 482.80 mA h g−1 at 1.0 mAcm−2 discharge current density, and a maximum power density of 4.88 mW cm−2 [311]. According to Xu et al., a novel Al-air battery with fibre-like shapes was created by progressively depositing a gel electrolyte and wrapping cross-stacked carbon nanotube (CNT)/silver nanoparticle hybrid sheets as the air cathode onto a spring-like Al substrate. This battery has an energy density of 1168 W h kg−1 and a specific capacity of 935 mA h g−1. The impressive electrochemical performance is a result of the creation of an electrode made of sheets of cross-stacked, aligned carbon nanotube and silver nanoparticles. The fiber structure also offers the Aluminum-air batteries special benefits, including flexibility and stretchability, as well as the ability to be woven into various fabrics for large-scale applications [312]. Aqueous electrolytes, non-aqueous electrolytes, solid electrolytes, organic electrolytes, ionic liquid electrolytes, and polymer-gel electrolytes are some of the numerous kinds of electrolytes used in Al-air batteries [313]. Polyvinyl alcohol-based electrolyte was used by Liu et al. to create an Al-air battery. Both polyethylene oxide (PEO) and N,N'-methylene bisacrylamide (MBA) were added to the polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) electrolyte for the Al-air battery to manage the conflict between mechanical and electrochemical features. At room temperature, the alkaline composite gel electrolyte achieves a conductivity of 2.1 × 10−1 S cm−1. The optimized gel Al-air battery in combination with pure Al has a power density of 44.5 mW cm−2. The gel's outstanding porosity structure guarantees the quick transfer of OH and Al(OH)4 −, extending the useful life of batteries. A functional, flexible Al-air gel battery pack was shown to power a smartphone in a demonstration [314]. With cellulose paper serving as the electrolyte substrate, low-grade aluminum foil serving as the anode, and carbon paper serving as the cathode, Wang et al. created an inexpensive paper-based Al-air battery. An open-circuit voltage of 1.6 V, a peak power density of 21 mW cm−2, and a specific capacity of 1273 mA h g−1 are achieved using an alkaline electrolyte. It has been shown that the transfer of electrolytes via paper may prevent Al from corroding in an alkaline environment, allowing for the direct use of low-grade Al resources. The development of a 5-cell battery pack was completed successfully, with an open-circuit voltage of 7.7 V and a stacking efficiency of up to 97% [315]. The high capacity, low cost, and environmental friendliness of flexible Al-air batteries have made them the preferred choice for the next generation of power sources for portable gadgets, including military communications, unmanned underwater vehicles (UUVs), and unmanned aerial vehicles. However, anodic parasite responses, pore blockage, slow oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) for non-noble cathodes and a lack of convincing reports for functional secondary Al-air batteries prevent them from being commercialised [305,314,316]. Further research on Al-air batteries must focus on reducing polarization and corrosion, incorporating carbonaceous materials as affordable and adaptable cathodes, utilizing ionic liquids and polymeric solid-state electrolytes, and using alloying metals that have a lower melting temperature than Al and a strong hydrogen overpotential [284,303,305,307,313,317-319]. 4.7 Zn-ion battery In a battery, Zn metal was initially employed as an electrode by Volta et al. in 1999. In primary and secondary Zn cells such as Ni-Zn batteries, MnO2-Zn batteries, Zn-ion batteries (ZIBs), and Zn-air batteries (ZABs), zinc metal has been judged to be the best anode material [320], due to Zn's low redox potential (−0.76 V against the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)), large theoretical capacity (820 mA h g−1), natural abundance, and non-toxicity [321]. Furthermore, the electrodeposition of zinc has been shown to be a successful procedure with coulombic efficiency (CE) >90%. Zn metal has high stability in aqueous electrolytes (alkaline, neutral, and mildly acidic). Zn rechargeable batteries are thus anticipated to become the most promising new energy storage technology [322].
