In comparison to magnesium and aluminium batteries, zinc batteries may be charged more effectively, with a slight self-discharge and high coulombic charging efficiency [323]. In terms of rechargeable Zn batteries, ZIBs stands out as the most suitable option [324]. Many investigators are becoming interested in Zinc-ion batteries. This is due to its desirable properties, such as its better volumetric energy density (i.e. 5855 mA h cm−3) and the reversibility of Zn plating/stripping. These qualities also enhance safety and lower toxicity [325]. When compared to an alkaline electrolyte, a neutral or slightly acidic electrolyte (pH 3.6–6.0) in aqueous ZIBs is more favourable to the suppression of Zn dendrite and irreversible by-products (such as ZnO) [326]. Yamamoto and Shoji created a rechargeable Zn-MnO2 battery with a mildly neutral ZnSO4 aqueous electrolyte in 1986 [327,328]. The ZIBs consist of a Zn anode, a mildly neutral aqueous electrolyte, and a substance that can store Zn ions as the cathode [329]. When conducting a discharge, Zn ions serve as the charge carriers and intercalate into the cathode, which then absorbs electrons as its oxidation state decreases. When conducting a reverse charge, however, the cathode releases Zn2+ , which is oxidized by the influence of the electric field [330]. The process can be summarized as follows. Anode: Zn ↔ Zn2+ + 2e– Cathode: M + xZn2+ + 2xe– ↔ Zn x M Overall: xZn + M ↔ Zn x M where M refer to the cathode materials [330]. A Schematic illustration of ZIB is provided in Fig. 17 . Recently, cathode materials for zinc-ion batteries have included manganese oxides, vanadium-based compounds, chalcogenides, Prussian blue analogues, and materials similar to NASICON [329]. Aqueous Zn-ion batteries with Zn-vanadium oxide cathodes were developed by Wang et al. They observed a spontaneous phase change from VOOH hollow nanospheres to hierarchically porous Zn0.3V2O51.5H2O (ZVO) nanoflowers. Aqueous Zn/ZVO batteries are made up of a 3 M Zn(CF3SO3)2 electrolyte, Zn anode, and VOOH nanosphere cathode. Fast electrochemical kinetics are made possible by the hierarchical nanoflowers' shape, which offers plenty of contact between the electrode and electrolyte as well as active Zn storage sites. Native crystal water and intercalated Zn ions in the interlayers act as pillars and lubricants to support the host structure and provide long-term cycle stability. The aqueous Zn/ZVO battery has a high specific capacity of 426 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1, a specific energy of 268 W h kg−1 at 1400 W kg−1 (cathode only), and long-term cycling stability with 96% capacity retention after 20,000 cycles at 10 A g−1 [331]. Given that the anode is often fixed with Zn alloys, a protective layer on Zn metal anodes seems to be a suitable technique [332] and aqueous electrolytes are flammable [326]. In order to prevent the growth of Zn dendrites and side reactions and promote uniform plating and stripping of Zn throughout the cycles, Lu et al. developed a bismuth (Bi)-PVDF layer with distinctive 3D cross-linked and branch-like structures as a protective layer on the Zn surface (Zn@Bi-PVDF). The cell has a constant capacity of 1 mA h cm−2 and a long cycle life of over 2400 h at a current density of 1 mA cm−2. The Zn@Bi-PVDF/NVO cell is manufactured using a Zn@Bi-PVDF anode and a NaV3O81.5H2O (NVO) cathode, and it retains a high reversible capacity of 175.5 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 500 cycles with an initial capacity retention of 64.1% [333]. Due to their excellent safety, low cost, and environmental friendliness, rechargeable Zinc-ion batteries are seen as a more practical choice for grid-scale applications [328]. However, a number of challenges remain, including the creation of Zn dendrites during the charge/discharge process, a small voltage window, low operating potential, H2 /O2 evolution, current collector corrosion, proton intercalation in aqueous electrolytes, a dearth of materials that are ideal for Zn-host cathodes, and unwanted Zn side reactions [334]. Further research on Zn-ion batteries must focus on (i) designing cathode materials (e.g. manganese oxide and vanadium-based materials) with high capacity and operating potential, (ii) preventing water decomposition to enhance the working voltage window by utilizing highly concentrated aqueous electrolyte, and (iii) ensuring Zn dissolution in non-alkaline electrolytes to enhance the system's working voltage [329]. 4.8 Zn-air battery Because Zn and the plentiful oxygen in the surrounding air are used to generate electricity, Zn-air batteries are a sustainable alternative [335]. Zn-air batteries have the potential to become a pillar technology for the future of global energy storage and supply due to their affordability, safety, high energy density (1218 W h kg−1), and accessibility of raw materials. It has a significant amount of promise for supplying both stationary energy utilities and EVs [336]. Technology for Zn-air batteries dates back a century. Smee first talked about the concept in 1840. Using a porous platinized carbon cathode, Maiche developed working primary Zn-air batteries in 1878. Zn-air primary battery commercial goods first appeared on the market in 1932 [337]. A Zn anode, an electrolyte (often concentrated KOH), and an air cathode make up a ZAB. The chemical reactions below explain the discharge mechanisms in ZABs [338]. Anode: Zn(s) + 4 OH− (aq) → Zn(OH)4 2− (aq) + 2 e− (E° = −1.25 V vs. SHE) Cathode: O2(g) + 2 H2O(aq) + 4 e− → 4 OH − (aq) (E° = +0.401 V vs. SHE) Overall reaction: 2 Zn(s) + O2(g) → 2 ZnO(s) (cell potential: 1.65 V) The Zn anode is transformed into soluble zincate ions during discharging by OH− oxidation. The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) takes place on the catalyst surface as O2 diffuses into the electrolyte from the air via the gas-diffusion layer and is transformed into OH−. The aforementioned electrochemical processes are reversible while the battery is charged. While soluble zincate ions are reduced to metallic Zn and deposited on the anode, OH− undergoes oxidation in the cathode via the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process [339]. A schematic illustration of the Zn-air battery is given in Fig. 18 . Zn metal and Zn alloys are used as anodes in Zn-air batteries. For use in Zn-air batteries, Peng et al. discovered a Zn-Sn alloy anode with repressible dendrite growth and meliorative corrosion resistance. As the anode for a Zn-air battery system, a dense and stable Zn-Sn alloy plate has been fabricated using the powder sintering technique. After 400 h of cycling at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2, the ideal Zn-Sn10 had a reduced voltage hysteresis of 119 mV. This alloy electrode performed well even at a high current density. The stable alloy structure of the Zn-Sn connection led to the Zn-Sn alloy electrode having increased corrosion resistance in an alkaline solution [341]. The current collector, hydrophilic layer (active catalyst), and hydrophobic layer/gas diffusion layer make up the air electrode [342]. A highly stable and active tungsten carbide electrocatalyst for rechargeable Zn-air batteries was created by Xu et al. Hydrothermal assisted vacuum rapid calcination was used to create the Fe, Co co-doped tungsten carbide/nitrogen-doped carbon catalyst (FeCo-WC/NC). The oxygen reduction reaction's energy barrier is lowered and the catalytic efficiency is increased by the Fe and Co with d-orbital multi-electron transition metals. FeCo-WC/NC demonstrated a high half-wave potential of 0.85 V, a high limiting current density of 5.62 mA cm−2, and outstanding stability. Successfully constructed Zn-air batteries using FeCo-WC/NC demonstrated a power density of 122.52 mW cm−2, a specific capacity of 744 mA h g−2, and remarkable cyclical stability [343]. Alkaline solution with a high concentration serves as the typical electrolyte in zinc-air batteries [344]. Using polyvinyl alcohol and hydroxy-functionalized MXene, Chen et al. presented a near-neutral gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) composite. The network of alkalized MXene within the PVA matrix functions as a water reservoir due to its three-dimensional porous structure and multiple surface-functionalized hydroxy groups, which improves water retention and results in a high ionic conductivity of 77.6 mS cm−1. The completed ZABs have a long cycle lifetime of 160 hours at a current density of 2 mA cm−2 and a charging-discharging interval of 15 min [345]. A high-performance Zn-air/silver hybrid secondary battery was reported by Mainar et al. This technique combines the high energy density and low-cost Zn-air technology with the high-power density silver-zinc technology. The practical properties of this battery are specified and analyzed at various silver loadings. With competitive specific energy (52.22 W h kg−1 Cell) and energy density, the reported secondary zinc-air/silver battery exhibits exceptional stability over 1000 h (253.64 W h L−1 Cell) [346]. Due to the limited cycle life of secondary Zn-air batteries, their broad employment has not yet been achieved, despite the fact that primary Zn-air batteries have been employed extensively in hearing aids, navigation lights, railway signalling systems, and military applications [339]. The performance of ZABs is also constrained by several basic problems, including passivation, hydrogen evolution reaction, dendritic growth, and shape or volume change of the Zn electrode [342]. The fabrication of rechargeable Zn-air batteries with superior electrochemical properties can be performed by adopting multifaceted approaches such as (i) usage of coating, alloying and electrolyte additives, (ii) understanding and improving the oxygen chemistry's slow response due to large ORR and OER overpotentials, (iii) utilizing non-noble metal catalysts such as perovskite, pyrochlore, and spinels, (iv) ensuring the smooth zinc(II) ion migration from anode to cathode, and (v) tailoring the pore size of separator's [140,347-349]. 5 Conclusions The development of clean and sustainable batteries is very important due to the scarcity of non-renewable fossil fuels and the associated environmental harms. One of the main challenges of the 21st century is finding reliable, affordable, and adaptable energy storage systems. Rechargeable batteries have been identified as the most promising alternatives to control electricity production and increase the power grid's tolerance for renewable energy. In order to meet the world's growing demand for energy, a variety of rechargeable energy storage systems, including Lead-acid, Ni-Cd, Ni-MH, Li-ion, Li-S, Li-O2, Li-CO2, Na-ion, Na-S, Mg-ion, K-ion, Al-ion, Al-air, Zinc-air and Zinc-ion battery systems, have been investigated. The timeline development of different rechargeable battery technologies is given in Fig. 19 . In spite of a number of safety concerns, lead-acid batteries continue to have a strong stand in the secondary battery industry due to their low cost and successful use of established industrial recycling techniques. Ni-Cd batteries are a popular kind of rechargeable battery for handheld electronics, but the toxicity of Cd and incineration of used Ni-Cd cells have significant ecological issues. Since the 1990s, Ni-MH batteries have been a popular power source for hybrid electric cars and house electrics due to their high-power density and safety. Ni-MH batteries possess a lower energy density than Li-ion batteries (LIB). The working characteristics of a nickel-metal hydride (Ni-MH) battery are better than those of a Ni-Cd cell in terms of specific energy, the absence of contamination, no memory effect. The achievable energy density of a Lead-acid battery is 35–40 W h kg−1, which is very low. The practical energy density of Ni-Cd cell is 50–75 W h kg−1. The practical value of the energy density of Ni-MH battery is 70–120 W h kg−1, which is much better than other conventional battery systems. More research should be done to increase the energy density of these conventional battery systems because the energy density is a very crucial factor in the battery field. LIB rechargeable batteries have made great progress in recent years because of their high energy density and long cycle life. These batteries are the standard power source for mobile electronics like smartphones, tablets, and laptops, and as such, they play a significant part in improving the standard of living in the modern era. Additionally, LIBs are the preferred choice for the electric car market. Despite their impressive capabilities, LIBs have several drawbacks, including a poor performance at low temperatures, high costs, an uneven distribution of Lithium resources in the earth's crust, and safety concerns. The solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) is a fatal decisive component for lithium-based battery performance. An ideal interface has good ionic conductivity and adequate electronic insulation, allowing ions to move quickly and preventing electron side reactions. The “solid electrolyte interphase (SEI)” is the common term for the interface that forms on the negative electrode. The “cathode electrolyte interphase (CEI)” is the interface that forms on the positive electrode, and the “electrode electrolyte interphase (EEI)” unifies the SEI and CEI. The electrode/electrolyte interface is essential for stabilizing the cycle performance and extending the useful life of rechargeable batterie [100]. Researchers have been working on Lithium based carbon dioxide batteries, which not only decrease carbon dioxide but also lessens our reliance on conventional fossil fuels. This revolutionary battery technology has received a lot of attention due to its theoretically high energy density and promise for CO2 collection. On the other hand, the discharging process leads to the irreversible creation of Li2CO3, which results in a large overpotential, a short cycle life, and a low-rate capability. As the cost of LIBs continues to rise, the availability of Li-resources across regions remains unequal, and safety issues persist, there has been a renewed focus on creating viable alternatives. As a result, it is essential to look into developing next-generation batteries for energy storage. Numerous ion-based battery technologies have garnered interest in recent years, including SIB, KIB, MIB, ZIB, and AIB batteries. The novel energy storage technology of SIBs is seen as a viable replacement for the more conventional LIBs in large-scale energy storage systems, owing to the availability and cheap cost of sodium raw materials. Except for the charge carrier, SIBs and LIBs have almost similar cell components and electrochemical reaction processes. Aluminium does not alloy with sodium and therefore current collector made from Aluminium may be employed in Sodium batteries for cost savings. In addition, the tools and methods used in LIBs might be used in SIBs to improve the effectiveness of production in the industrial sector. The combination of these benefits makes SIBs promising investments for a wide range of emerging energy markets. When it comes to improving the economy, improving infrastructure, and adapting to a changing climate, the use of SIBs is very important. This technology has several challenges, the most significant of which are its low energy density and specific capacity, poor cycle performance, and slow rate. Finding and improving novel electrode materials and electrolytes is crucial in the development of commercially viable SIBs to provide cheaper, safer, and longer-lasting products. MIBs are attractive because of their high volumetric energy density, minimal safety concerns, two-electron redox, and the widespread availability and low environmental impact of magnesium. Because of its potential use in harsh conditions, studies examining MIBs electrochemical performance at high and ultra-low temperatures have drawn significant interest for military and space station purposes. Diverse cathodes, anodes, electrolytes, and interfacial phenomena are being studied in depth to suit the needs for operating these MIBs across broad temperature ranges. Despite these advantages, contemporary MIBs are hampered by issues such as low energy density, low rate, and low cyclic stability due to inadequate cathode material availability, poor electrochemical stability of electrolytes, and irreversible Mg/Mg2+ stripping/plating at the anode. It is well understood that the anode, cathode, and electrolyte of a magnesium-ion cell have a profound impact on the cell's overall performance, and that each component is now the subject of design efforts by futuristic MIBs. KIBs are popular owing to their availability, high-working voltages, and chemical resemblance to Li, which allows them to use existing Li-ion technology. Unfortunately, there are several obstacles in the way of KIB development because of the enormous radius of K+, the extreme volume expansion during insertion/de-insertion, and the subsequent fall in capacity. Adequate anode materials are crucial to accelerating the widespread use of KIBs. Unlike LIBs and SIBs, MIBs, AIBs, ZIBs, and KIBs are still in the early stages of development. AIBs, with their three-electron redox characteristics, low flammability, cheap cost, and high cycle performance, are now attracting a lot of attention in the battery research field. AIBs are still in their early stages of development, and it is difficult to achieve high voltage, high specific capacity, and high stability using multivalent Al3+. So, we need to begin with the electrolyte investigation, positive electrode design, Al protection, and battery assembly all at once to tackle the issues with AIBs and boost the electrochemical kinetics. ZIBs, a kind of multivalent ion battery, offer high volumetric energy density with a two-electron transfer, inherent safety, environmental friendliness, great abundance, and recyclability. Zn dendrite limits the practical usage of commercial zn metal as an anode due to its high-volume change and structural breakdown after repeated cycling. The plating of Zn on a conductive substrate is a promising approach to solving the aforesaid difficulties. To address the issues associated with the established and developing energy storage technologies researchers are exploring alternate sulfur -based energy storage systems. The Li-S with its sulfur-carbon (S-C) composite cathode and Li metal anode is an exciting “beyond-LIB” technology for large-scale applications, as both S and Li metal display enormous specific capacities (S: 1675 mA h g−1; Li: 3862 mA h g−1). Practical Li-S batteries with high-sulfur-loading cathodes, lean electrolytes, and reduced anode excess should be emphasized to achieve high energy density. Such limits redefine research bounds, and new obstacles arise as the bottleneck of practical Li-S batteries, such as poor ionic conductivity, the shuttle effect, poor cycling performance and quick lithium metal anode failure in pouch cells. Furthermore, extensive research on the novel Li-S chemistry should be conducted in order to bridge the gap between lab scale and practical scale, as well as industrial production [350]. To increase the sustainability of Li-S batteries, future research should focus on the efficient design of the S–C composite electrode, electrolyte, and the Li metal. The Li-S batteries seem to have a higher chance of maturing and becoming commercially viable. Sodium-sulfur (Na-S) batteries are seen as a superior option to Li-S batteries due to the availability and cost-effectiveness of their constituent components. High-temperature Na-S (HT-Na/S) batteries are limited in their usefulness due to the extra expense of battery maintenance and possible safety issues produced by the high operating temperature. However, because of their naturally available sulfur and sodium, high theoretical specific capacity, and eco-friendly design, room-temperature sodium-sulfur (RT Na-S) batteries have emerged as a promising option for next-generation potential energy storage systems. Since the reaction kinetics are slow and the longer Na-polysulfides (Na2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) dissolve quickly into the liquid electrolyte, Na-S batteries at room temperature have a low practical capacity and a short cycle life. Solutions to the shuttle effect include developing effective polymer gel electrolytes, discovering a new cathode material to replace elemental sulfur, and using a solid electrolyte rather than a liquid one. The practical deployment of RT Na-S batteries is still difficult to accomplish, despite recent advancements. A lot of people are looking into metal-air batteries (MABs) as potential technologies of the future. Li-air batteries, Zn-air batteries, and Al-air batteries are the main examples of MABs that have been produced so far. These MABs are not all created equal, they each have their own set of strengths and weaknesses. The high energy density of lithium-air batteries (11,586 W h kg−1) makes them an interesting technology for usage in energy storage systems. To use this battery in open air is a complicated process, and commercialization of this technology requires the development of cathodes with optimal porosity, surface area, and mass load. People are starting to take notice of rechargeable Zn-air batteries because of their many desirable characteristics (high theoretical energy density, high safety, plentiful reserves, environmental friendliness, cheap cost, etc.). The slow dynamics and weak overpotential of ZABs during the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are two of their biggest drawbacks. For several reasons, including its cheap price, good performance, and high energy density, the Al-air battery has been seen as a particularly promising primary battery technology. Insufficient ORR kinetics of cathode catalysts has prevented the commercialization of Al-air batteries. Studying these air batteries is still in its infancy, and more serious and dedicated efforts are required. A solid-state battery is an emerging technology for electrochemical energy storage systems. Such batteries use solid electrodes and a solid electrolyte instead of liquid or polymer gel electrolytes. These batteries can provide potential solutions for many problems of conventional liquid electrolyte-based batteries, such as flammability and leakage problems, while maintaining a sufficient voltage range and electrochemical properties. In addition to their excellent safety, these batteries are expected to provide a wide range of operating temperatures and less dendritic growth to next-generation battery systems. The advantages and limitations of various rechargeable battery systems are shown in Table 1 . The possible applications of rechargeable battery systems in transportation, portable electronics, and grid/ stationary energy storage are highlighted in Fig. 20 . This review of electrochemical rechargeable battery systems reveals that Lead-acid, Ni-Cd, Ni-MH batteries are still in widespread usage due to their simple design and low cost. The recycling, safety, low capacity and bulky design are the major drawbacks of these conventional rechargeable battery systems. The LIBs have captured the portable electronics industry and slowly and gradually becoming the preferred choice for electric vehicles. Among the metal-ions batteries, when size is not the primary factor SIBs may provide a big opportunity to replace the existing storage technology, such as LIBs In the future. However, the Mg-ion, Al-ion, Zn-ion and K-ion batteries have a long journeyto go to address the issues of recyclability, low capacity, low efficiency, and low operating voltage. The metal-sulfur batteries, i.e., Li-S and Na-S batteries, have the promise of providing high energy density from low-cost sulfur active material. Sulfur is a waste from the oil and gas industry and thus helps in protecting and balancing the environment. The Li-air, Al-air, and Zn-air batteries are attractive and have the ability to provide high energy densities. However, the slow dynamics of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), low anode utilization, and explosion of organic liquid electrolytes are some of the challenges in these air batteries. The diverse alternate energy storage technologies have a wide gap between theoretical and practical values. The gap is required to be reduce by synergetic efforts from the research fields of electrochemical catalysis, theoretical calculations, and nanoscience, more breakthroughs on these batteries can be achieved, and they can contribute to rapidly expanding commercial applications. coredata.dc:description: The present and future energy requirements of mankind can be fulfilled with sustained research and development efforts by global scientists. The purpose of this review paper is to provide an overview of the fundamentals, recent advancements on Lithium and non-Lithium electrochemical rechargeable battery systems, and their future prospects. The initial part of this review paper is dedicated to the advancement and challenges faced by the conventional rechargeable batteries, such as lead-acid, Ni-Cd and Ni-MH batteries. The subsequent section of this review focuses on an in-depth analysis of two major categories of rechargeable batteries, namely lithium-based rechargeable battery systems and alternative non-Lithium rechargeable battery systems. The working principle, construction, and a few important research progress on Li-ion, Li-O2, Li-CO2 and Li-S batteries have been highlighted. The recent progress and challenges of the alternate batteries such as Na-ion, Na-S, Mg-ion, K-ion, Al-ion, Al-air, Zn-ion and Zn-air are also discussed in this review. The large gap between theoretical and practical electrochemical values for the alternate battery system must be filled by adopting a series of design architectures followed by modern instrumentation for developing next-generation batteries in a sustainable and efficient way.
